This is an opportune time for us all to reflect on the circumstances that gave rise to this stockpile freeze, because they demonstrate the absolute incompetence and lack of political will by National Party ministers in this coalition government. The decision to freeze the stockpile was not made on the basis of any rational commercial imperative; it was made for political reasons as the Liberal and National parties cowered at the foot of One Nation before the last election.
We all know that most of the industry opposed this freeze. It is a matter of public record also that the minister for agriculture at the time also opposed the freeze, and he took that position to the cabinet table. But it was the National Party ministers, weak as they were, who got rolled over by a Liberal Prime Minister and a rural Liberal from WA who happened to have the Prime Minister's ear on this particular issue. Some claim to fame, isn't 
 it? National Party Ministers Vaile, Anderson, Fischer and others around the table getting done over by the member for O'Connor and a bevy of urban lawyers and Liberal stockbrokers who could see the electoral fortunes of the coalition disappearing down the One Nation tunnel.
The wool stockpile freeze was no more than an act of political cowardice by an incompetent government that lost its political nerve in the face of the rise of One Nation which threatened its constituency in rural and regional Australia. It was one of the worst examples of political panic and `policy on the run' that we have seen yet from this ramshackle coalition. The simple fact is that the stockpile of around one million bales remains.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—The honourable member for Forrest certainly does not like hearing this, but it is the truth of the matter.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. This debate is to do with the legislation. The member for Corio is not addressing that issue. He is certainly way off the mark with his comments. I would ask you to bring him to the legislation.
—I call the member for Corio. I think he is talking about the issue, albeit in a way that probably gives some offence to the member for Mallee, but I think he is in order.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I can understand the sensitivity of the honourable member for Mallee on this matter. I am sure that, if he was around that table, being the honourable man that he is, he would not have caved in like Ministers Vaile and Anderson did to the Liberal lawyers and the stockbrokers who ran all over them for political reasons and threw out the economic imperative in  considering the future of this industry. If you cannot bear me on the floor of this House talking about the stockpile and the historical facts of the matter, then there is something wrong with the lot of you. As we debate this bill today, if the government permitted Wool International to continue the orderly sell-down of the stockpile, there would be a 
 much smaller stockpile today to manage and the cost to wool growers of holding and storing the remainder would certainly be less.
With regard to this legislation, the minister's second reading speech has outlined in some detail the process by which it proposes to privatise Wool International and the new commercial structure to be known as WoolStock Australia that will manage further sales once this legislation is passed by the parliament. I have already referred to wool grower concerns about the lack of consultation with industry during the process of developing the new commercial structure. That level of consultation improved considerably once the matter was raised by the opposition and other interested parties in the public arena. But there are some technical and other concerns that still remain.
Concerns have been raised about the 1.2 per cent of equity unit holders in Wool International who cannot be traced and the more substantial problem of the 25 per cent of unit holders whose equity is held in names that are not legal entities. This is a problem that will have to be faced by the new WoolStock Australia. At the Senate committee hearing evidence was given that these people certainly answered correspondence and bank cheques but so far have not responded to requests to provide correct legal names to allow their shares to be registered. I pass no further comment on the evidence that was given at that inquiry. This has had some implications for the structure of the new privatised entity with those shares to be held now under this legislation in a subsidiary trust company whose directors will be appointed by the board of WoolStock Australia, and who will be required to conduct their affairs in the interests of the beneficiaries of the trust as per normal commercial practice in these situations.
Some concerns have also been expressed by certain producers at their level of representation at the board level in the new commercialised structure. This has always been an issue which has confronted agricultural ministers of all political persuasions in attempting to marry the appropriate grower representation with commercial and marketing expertise at 
 the board level. Indeed, I need to go no further on this matter than to reiterate the importance of appropriately balancing producer interests and commercial expertise in this matter with the confidence of growers and others in this industry.
One area of additional concern is the proposed power under this legislation of WoolStock Australia, in addition to selling down the wool pile and distributing the available proceeds to unit holders. The company has been given the power to spend $3 million, as the minister has put it in his second reading speech, to investigate and possibly support new business activities. There is a lack of clarity as to what sorts of business activities might become the subject of allocation from grower funds. One hopes that this $3 million will not end up lining the pockets of expensive consultants engaged to investigate new business activities that, at the end of the day, are not taken up by the company or are of little long-term value to Australian wool growers.
There has been little public discussion as to the type of possible new business activities WoolStock Australia might engage in in the marketplace, and care must be taken to ensure that any potential activity does not prejudice the commercial interests of growers currently holding new product on farm. This brings me to the sell-down strategy that might be pursued by WoolStock Australia and the potential for long-term harm to growers in the marketplace if this sell-down strategy is not handled correctly. This matter has not been aired or debated fully within the industry, in my view. When Labor set up Wool International to dispose of the stockpile, we set in place an orderly mechanism for the sell-down. That program was modified over time and made more flexible to take account of current market conditions and to protect the long-term interests of growers. The orderly sell-down principle introduced a measure of certainty and predictability into the wool marketplace and, over time, generated a degree of credibility and confidence in the ability of the industry and the government to manage a very difficult market situation.
The industry is aware of proposals by reputable players with strong financial backing to purchase the stockpile lock, stock, and barrel. In raising this matter, I do not wish in any way to prejudice those proposals, which have already been put on the table for consideration, as they have to be examined closely for their commercial viability and their long-term benefit to equity holders in the stockpile. However, the manner of disposal of the stockpile, should it be purchased by a single buyer, and its commercial implications for growers, needs to be thoroughly analysed and discussed at this stage of the debate.
May I conclude my remarks in this debate by restating my firm belief that this is a great rural industry with enormous potential to consolidate its position in the marketplace and, indeed, to expand its production. I am aware of the pessimism that currently pervades the industry. With flock numbers declining, low prices occurring in the marketplace, a decline in the industry's export performance and an oversupply of wool, many growers are naturally fearful for their future in the industry.
It does not help industry morale to have an incompetent government making decisions on the run that destroy the credibility of the industry in the marketplace. Nor does it help when articles appear in the daily press that quote members of the government's taskforce saying that half of the nation's 46,000 wool growers will be wiped out in five years. That report was contained in an article that appeared in the business section of the Age newspaper of 10 May 1999.
 There have been many inquiries into the wool industry in recent times. One can forgive wool growers for the fair degree of cynicism that accompanied the government's decision to establish a wool industry taskforce to develop a future blueprint for the industry. It is not enough for this government to simply wash its hands of this industry with simple catchcries about putting the industry's future back into growers' hands. This is a national industry with many participants and large investments tied up in it. Its survival is important to rural and regional communities and its export success is important to the 
 nation's global trading performance. On that basis, there is a responsibility on the part of national government to guide and assist this industry in a creative way to a greater level of prosperity than it is currently enjoying.
One does not need a bevy of reports to restate the obvious steps that must be taken for this industry to secure its future. In making that statement, let me say that there will be no simple solution, only a continuing effort by all participants in the chain to seek efficiencies, to improve productivity and to play their part in developing a secure future for this industry. One key to the commercial future of wool lies simply in the generation of greater demand for the product.
The industry is well aware of the competition it currently faces from synthetic and other fibres, and there needs to be a dramatic improvement in the industry's marketing efforts to stimulate a long-term improvement in the demand for wool. That will only come about through the development of new products and designs aimed at a much wider market than currently exists. In addition, the opening up of new geographical markets for wool will be important in sustaining demand in the longer term. It is pleasing to see that this industry is making some inroads into new markets in places like Turkey and India at a time of significant weakness in the international market in those traditional areas that we have exported to in Europe and North Asia.
It is clear that the wool industry has yet to come to terms with the need for a greater unity of purpose among wool growers themselves and among other players in the industry. I think the government does have an active role to play here in encouraging the development of an industry plan that sets out clearly where the industry wants to be in the next five-, 10-and 15-year periods and what needs to be done to secure the future of the industry over that time.
Labor governments know all about successful industry planning. In 13 years of government, we turned many industries in the manufacturing and rural sectors around from inward-looking industries to ones where we now have a very strong domestic production base and a good export performance. I refer 
 here to the car industry, the pharmaceuticals industry and, of course, the dairy industry. These are all testament to Labor's capacity in government to get an industry into growth mode and to secure its future. That is the challenge for this minister and for this government as far as this industry is concerned.
It is also clear that the current production structure of the industry must change. Currently, it is estimated that the bottom third of farms are running fewer than 1,000 sheep and producing around 5.5 per cent of the total output of the industry. These growers produce a limited number of bales for sale in small lots, which creates additional handling costs further down the production chain. The task for government is to not only assist in the necessary changes that will see some producers stay and become more productive and more efficient, but also create a decent exit mechanism for those who choose to leave. We sincerely hope that it is not going to be at the level predicted in the newspaper article by some members of the government's task force, which stated that about half of the 46,000 wool producers in this country would go to the wall or withdraw from the industry in the next five years. It is also clear that at the moment there are far too many links in the production, distribution and marketing chain which effectively distort the price signals to producers. Rationalisation here will be painful but it will be required to improve the price and marketing signals that come directly to producers.
It is very clear that the culture of this industry will have to change for it to secure its future. I think producers are aware of what will be required of them in securing the future of the industry. Their task on farm will be to address the issue of greater productivity, to engage in the task of quality assurance, to improve their risk management procedures and to get into the greater use of information technology to improve their productivity and efficiency. The era of electronic selling of this product is certainly at hand. There are great efficiencies to be made not only through electronic selling but also in the handling task. 
In conclusion, let me reiterate the point that I made earlier. The opposition does not accept the proposition that this is an industry in terminal decline. I believe that it has extraordinary potential to develop but that it is in need of radical change. There must be strong leadership from this minister and this government in securing the sort of change that is going to lead to this industry re-establishing itself in its pre-eminent place in the marketplace as one of Australia's major rural industries. The task will fall to producers in the manner that I have outlined to improve their on farm performance, and I believe they are up to the task. There are many shining examples in this industry of specialist producers who produce only wool; they do not rely on the production of other commodities. They are extremely profitable and able, through their own internal management and on farm practices, to read market signals correctly and produce their product in a way that is suitable for the next level in the chain of processing and handling.
This is an industry with exciting potential. As I said, governments must display leadership and the industry itself must come to terms with these great challenges. There will be some casualties in the wool industry over the next five years, but the task for government and industry leaders is to ensure that the productive capacity of this industry remains intact so that, when the winds of change sweep across the marketplace—when changes are made to the marketing of this product and when there is an improvement in demand—the capacity exists to meet it. The prosperity that will flow as a result of that to rural and regional communities can be secured.
I do not think this industry has really been given a fair shake from this government in the policy responses that we have seen over the last three years. The government has been elected for another three years; it may not last that long. If the GST does not get through the Senate, we might find ourselves in a situation where this government is retired earlier than expected. But it may well go its full term. I can only hope that the processes that it has set in place through this legislation and through the wool industry task force yield real 
 fruit for this industry. The time for more reports on the wool industry in Australia is really over. It is time for the industry itself to come to terms with the real structural changes that are going to be required to propel it into a new era of prosperity. The task is there for government to provide the necessary assistance and support to this key rural industry to secure its future not only for the producers in the industry but also for those in rural and regional Australia—those communities that rely very much on this industry for their survival.

name: Forrest, John, MP
text:
—This seems a little like deja vu. I remember following the member for Corio in the debate on the Wool International Amendment Bill which was the enabling legislation—and this is the second tranche of it—in which he made some unfortunate remarks. He actually finished up much better than he started by sharing some of the aspirations that I have for the Australian wool industry.
To make some allowance for the member for Corio, unlike me he does not have the personal contact and relationship that I have with 4,500 wool growers. In his contribution to this debate he asked what my position was back in October 1998 in respect of the future of the stockpile. I was one of the members who listened to growers at the coalface and advocated the freezing of the stockpile.
Mr Adams interjecting—
—For the right reasons. I was delighted with the positive response that that had on the eastern market indicator immediately. The member for Corio made reference to a comment in the minister's second reading speech in respect of this legislation. He referred to the minister's comment that the stockpile was an Achilles heel for the industry. The point that the member for Corio seems to miss—and I would like the member for Lyons to take particular note of this—is that the stockpile itself is not the Achilles heel; it is the uncertainty of its release onto the marketplace. I hope that members of the Australian Labor Party can understand this. It has always been the uncertainty surrounding the release of the 
 stockpile onto the market that made the market nervous.
Prior to my entering parliament in 1993 the size of the stockpile had accumulated to 4.7 million bales. It was more than an Achilles heel; it was a sword of Damocles hanging over the market as to what would be the future of the stockpile. I am a little disappointed with the member for Corio's contribution and his condemnation of the government's leadership in respect of what has been done since 1996. He ought to check the history books to find what happened prior to that date throughout the late 1980s which allowed this huge stockpile to be accumulated in the first place. However, there is no need to repeat history. Let us focus on the positives now and the future of what is—and he at least agrees—one of Australia's icon industries and part of the backbone of rural Australia.
Mr Adams interjecting—
—The member for Lyons will get his opportunity, which I have no doubt he will take. This bill provides for the conversion of Wool International into a company operating under Corporations Law, WoolStock Australia. We have waited a long time to place that so-called Achilles heel into a commercial atmosphere so that releases from the stockpile from that point on can be based on proper commercial decisions, instead of releasing a valuable commodity at whatever price we can get. We can say, `We are sorry. This is the price at which we expect you to buy our product.' We do not need to just accept any price, which has been the difficulty over the years.
I have brought along with me some evidence of what has occurred with the eastern market indicator and the tragedy of the wool industry going right back to the late 1980s and more particularly in the last eight or nine months since the debate about the current size of the stockpile has featured so much amongst wool growers and their representative bodies. From March 1988 until about August 1998 we suffered an absolute free fall in the eastern market indicator. The market had one million bales and was wondering whether it would be released and whether there would be change.
The government immediately showed leadership and declared its intention to freeze the stockpile and provide for what has occurred since, that is, the legislation before us today and a basis on which to commercialise the stockpile. This arrested that decline and in fact we saw some slight improvement.
Since the start of this year, and since the enabling legislation was debated in this House in November last year, there has been an improvement in that market price indicator from as low as 450c up to 550c or 560c where it currently sits. That is sufficient proof in the pudding. It has put a floor in the market for the wool industry and has given them something on which to build their future.
I repeat the remarks that I made in this chamber back in November. Here we have an industry that still has the capacity to grow, which the member for Corio thankfully agrees with, despite the cheap politics in the early part of his remarks. I expect him to unite with us and support this legislation in its entirety and support the public debate. If he wants to be the shadow spokesman on primary industries, he must learn the difficulty there always is in getting a single and sound voice from a dispersed rural electorate or any particular commodity industry because of the different commodities produced all over this diverse nation. He needs to develop the capacity to hear that.
I have listened to the people at grassroots level in my electorate—the wool growers who sent me to this place—and they applaud this legislation. They applaud the fact that, finally, after a decade of uncertainty, this stockpile will be predicted by commercial and not political decisions. The market can be more relaxed. They can cope with the uncertainties that they already have. Things were going not so badly until disaster struck Asia, particularly our valuable markets in Japan and other Asian locations. This will now put some certainty into the way in which these releases will be made from the stockpile.
I support this legislation in its entirety. I am very relieved that it is finally before the parliament. I hope that all members—not only in this place but also in the other place—will 
 give it speedy passage to allow what needs to occur from now on to actually occur, that is, to determine a proper business plan and establish an environment in which we might be able to realise whatever commercial offer there could be to purchase the entirety of the stockpile. We need to test that. There has been plenty of discussion and suggestion, and that must be tested as soon as we can.
The minister has made some substantial announcements in respect of the various personnel who will be involved with WoolStock Australia. Mr Donald McGauchie will be chairman and he has my unqualified support. He is a person whom I know very well. He understands rural Australia and commodity issues. He is already demonstrating why the minister has selected him to be chairman of WoolStock Australia.
I will be looking forward to a comprehensive plan that establishes the future for our icon Australian wool industry. I look forward to working with my wool growers and their new wool growing and marketing associations and meeting the challenges with which they will be confronted. We have had decades of competitive fibres stealing the march on wool. We now have alternative fibres that blend wool. They have stolen the march because we have had this dreadful uncertainty with the stockpile which has hung over the marketplace and been responsible for a collapse in wool prices.
It has meant real and direct pain for my wool growing constituency of about 4,500 wool growers—and that is approximately 10,000 people or about 5,000 families. There have been repercussions to the wool industry through important provincial cities and townships in regions like the Wimmera, and certainly through the member for Wannon's region in south-west Victoria. I am delighted that the leadership shown by the government on this matter has put a floor on the price of wool. I am confident that in 12 months, if I look at a graph for the eastern market indicator for the sale of wool, I will see it increasing from its current level of 560c.
I take this opportunity to congratulate the government for a number of initiatives that they have included in this bill—particularly 
 for exempting WoolStock Australia from income tax on its stockpile activities. I think it would be inappropriate for the government to try to take the opportunity to consolidate its revenue and to take the opportunity for the investment that exists in that stockpile. I congratulate the minister and the government for that initiative. In addition, measures will apply to exclude the application of capital gains tax to unit holdings. It is appropriate that, where growers have contributed their own money through compulsory taxation to support the stockpile, that they be given exemptions from capital gains tax. I congratulate the government for that.
In conclusion, let me go back to the comments made by the member for Corio in respect of the partisanship he is trying to engender in the debate today. He would have endeared himself much more to the wool growing constituency of Australia if he had come into the chamber and said that he fully supported this legislation and commended the government for its initiative rather than taking cheap political points about a decision that was made in respect of the stockpile—which was right and made for the right reasons. To suggest that it was because of some political opportunism of the day smacks of a complete misunderstanding of what is happening to wool growers at the coalface.
The proof is in the pudding—the proof is in the immediate impacts it has had on the price of wool. The shadow minister ought to be condemned for trying to make cheap political points. This industry badly needs bipartisan support and a united parliament to get it back on its feet so that, once again, it can be that icon industry. We often say how this nation was created by the wool that came from the sheep's back. We owe this industry because that is in fact true. I am confident that it will still enjoy, as the future will demonstrate, that status amongst our rural primary industry.
I am delighted to stand here today in support of this legislation. I urge all other members of this place and the other place to do the same.

name: Adams, Dick, MP
text:
—I do not have very much time to remark on the Wool International Privatisation Bill 1999 . This bill 
 is finally tidying up the threads that the government left hanging before the last election when it instigated a freeze and then found that it had a problem. Wool International was required, under the previous legislation, to sell 90,000 to 135,000 bales per quarter, and the government got itself into a bind because it could not sell wool at that time.
If I remember rightly, this was all brought on by One Nation making inroads into the National and Liberal Party territory before the last election—members totally panicked, ran off all over the place and made these silly decisions by freezing the wool stockpile. They wobbled all over the place and raced off to the Prime Minister. I understand the National Party minister stood his ground, but he was totally rolled. Again, the lawyers and stockbrokers of Sydney and Melbourne dictated rural policy to the National Party, and the National Party was knocked straight over and straight out of the debate. What was decided by the lawyers and stockbrokers of Melbourne and Sydney was run that day and won the day. It does not matter what the member for Mallee says, that is the position and that is what happened. The freeze was a mistake; it should never have occurred. If it had not occurred, about 300,000 to 500,000 bales of wool could have been sold and we would have continued to wind down the wool stockpile, going towards a new future in wool.
The member for Mallee did not mention the future except to say that it was going to be all rosy. He did not get into any of the issues that have to occur in the wool industry in order to make a future. Great structural changes have to occur and need to be addressed, and they are not being addressed by that side of the House in any way.
I say to the member for Mallee and to others on that side of the House: you have to start looking at the future of the wool industry and to start talking about it. I do not think that this bill has very much in it at all about the future of the wool industry; there is not much innovation in it at all. There is $3 million in it—some sort of investment direction. I think that is about giving mates a few more consultants' fees—that is all that is 
 going to come out of that $3 million. I do not think anything constructive will come out of it. This freeze on the wool stockpile came about because the Liberal Party rolled the National Party. I see the minister in the chamber. I understand he stood his ground; it was the lawyers and the stockbrokers that knocked over—
—Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The member for Lyons will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

name: Crean, Simon, MP
text: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Treasurer, do you recall criticising Labor's economic growth on the grounds that it was overwhelmingly based on consumption and lacked the necessary level of business investment to make it sustainable? Doesn't your budget growth forecast rely just as heavily on consumption and doesn't Treasury, in the budget papers, raise uncertainty about that consumption? If, as Treasury fears, consumption is weaker than forecast, just where is the growth going to come from?

name: Costello, Peter, MP
text: —I am overwhelmed by the attack. The budget forecasts growth in 1999-2000 of around three per cent. Three per cent growth in 1999-2000, while down somewhat on this year, will be stronger than Europe, the United States, the OECD and G7. Consumption will be strong in the forthcoming year, and that is principally because of low interest rates. For the average Australian with the average mortgage, since this government was elected, interest rates have fallen by four per cent. That is a saving of about $320 a month, and I am sure that in the early days many people took the opportunity to reduce the term of their mortgages. But, now there is a bit more money around, obviously retail spending is strong, and that is keeping the Australian economy strong at a time of slow world growth. I think all members of the House would be pleased about that.

name: Price, Roger, MP
text:
—Mr Speaker, I do not want to raise the current problems members are having with Outlook but, rather, to draw your attention to the fact that you have not so far reconstituted the Presiding Officers Information Technology Advisory Group, POITAG, that you and your successors going back some years formed. Could you advise honourable members whether your intention is to do so? If so, when? If not, would you be able to outline to honourable members the reasons for such a decision?
Mr SPEAKER—I will happily respond immediately to that question. The member for Chifley first raised, I think, the difficulty some members are experiencing with email today. That seems to be something that is rather more the unfortunate coincidence of members having a large email load following the Budget coinciding with the workplace relations negotiations that are currently going on also overloading the email. I am told the matter should be cleared this afternoon. So far as POITAG, as it is known, goes, I have already taken steps to reconstitute the POITAG committee.

name: Crean, Simon, MP
text:
—The fourth Costello budget is a budget of missed opportunities, wrong priorities and it is not the real budget. It is not the real budget because it is based on three assumptions, any one of which could fall over. The first of those assumptions is that the GST will get through, even though no additional compensation is provided for within it. Everyone knows this GST is deficient. We have had evidence before the Senate inquiry demonstrating that there will be significant losers. The Prime Minister went to the electorate seeking a mandate for the GST on the basis that there would be not one loser. Yet there is no additional compensation in this budget for the GST. That is the first assumption which could fall over.
The second assumption is that it is based on 100 per cent sale of Telstra. We have heard the weasel words today in the parliament, but the truth of the matter is that the Leader of the National Party, the coalition partner, had to ward off the palace revolt within his own 
 party about the further sell-down of Telstra. He has made a commitment not just to his own party but also to regional Australia that there will not be 100 per cent sell-off of Telstra until such time as that can be justified through a full public inquiry. Yet this budget dishonestly includes the full sale of Telstra as the basis for its forward estimates. That is the second assumption that could fall over.
The third is that the growth in this budget is heavily reliant on consumption. There are two aspects of this. One is that the Treasury itself casts serious questions over this assumption of continued strong consumption. In the budget papers there is heavy qualification by the Treasury of this assumption. It says on page 2-14:
One important uncertainty surrounding the outlook for household consumption is the . . . downward trend in the household saving ratio and rising household debt. . . . consumption expenditure could be weaker than forecast.
Yet this is the basis upon which the budget projects stronger growth continuing. That is the first point—the Treasury itself not sharing the Treasurer's optimism. We heard the Treasurer today reinforce that optimism about strong growth. Also, the growth is wrongly structured, with its heavy emphasis on consumption. We do not deny that consumption—expenditure, if you like, turning the economy over—is an important contributor to growth, but consumption as the predominant driver will not sustain growth because you need investment, you need exports.
In other words, you need balance and structure in underpinning that growth. We have argued that this government has taken its eye off those important drivers of growth—the things that will really encourage stronger investment, the things that will drive our exports. But it is not just Labor that says that the structure and the emphasis on consumption is wrong to justify continuing optimism about stronger growth; the Treasurer himself has said that. I will quote what the now Treasurer said in 1994. This is criticising Labor's growth. On page of 1207 of Hansard, he said:
What we need is sustained recovery built on sound foundations . . . But, as the Treasurer himself— 

that is, the Labor Treasurer—
admitted in his press conference earlier this afternoon, it is a growth—
that is, Labor's growth—
based on consumption . . . It is not growth which is soundly based on business investment, on new plant and equipment or on industry and business picking up, investing and employing.
So here you have the Treasurer criticising Labor budgets for their heavy reliance on consumption, and yet his own budget, his own confidence, is built on the same heavy reliance. The Treasurer cannot have it both ways. He cannot say Labor's growth was bad, but his growth was good. The truth of it is that Treasury itself does not share the optimism about that growth.
What we have before us is not the real budget. If the GST does not pass, if they do not sell 100 per cent of Telstra, if they do not get the consumption that they are looking for, this budget will fall over. What we have got is a phantom budget, a dishonest budget. It is dishonest for this reason: it is structured on claiming all of the revenue gains from a GST, yet none of the economic impact of the GST. Take prices for example—the point of the question that the Treasurer would not answer today. We know from Treasury evidence before the Senate inquiry that the first-year effect of the GST coming in will be to lift inflation by an additional 3.1 per cent, not 1.9 per cent.
—Nonsense.
—Are you saying that Treasury is talking nonsense, my friend? Are you saying Treasury is talking nonsense? They have given this in evidence. The Treasurer will not even answer this question in this parliament. I will tell you what I would rely on: I would rely on that which is said in evidence because those people know the consequences of not telling the truth. This government has not learnt from the fact that it does not tell the truth; it continues to perpetuate the dishonesty. But this is what the budget actually says, on page 111:
The impact on prices of the tax reform under a new tax system is not—
I emphasise `not'—
included in the projections.
Why not, Mr Deputy Speaker? They have included the revenue. They like to take the good parts to bolster the justification for their surplus and put the pressure on in the Senate. They want to grab the gains but they do not want to identify the economic impact. They have deliberately ruled out the inflation impact. Nowhere in here do we see the employment impact. Nowhere in here do we have the consequences for wages growth—which, as demonstrated in evidence before the Senate process, could increase. Nowhere is that factored into this. That is why it is a dishonest budget. But it is not just that they are claiming revenue off the GST without balancing that with the downside of the GST; they are also claiming the revenue from the full sale of Telstra, even though they told us in the House today they are only going to sell 16 per cent. How can you believe this document? This document is a joke. It is not the real budget. It is a dishonest budget. The truth of the matter is that the GST is bad for the economy.
I will tell you why those figures are not in the budget. It is because Treasury disagrees with the political rhetoric that this government has been running. The Treasurer has been out trumpeting this great GST, saying, `It'll be good for jobs, good for growth, good for this. It's snake oil—it'll fix everything.' Yet not one piece of evidence has been produced by this government to justify those claims. To the contrary: we have produced evidence in the Senate that refutes those claims, that says it is bad for the economy. It is not just unfair to pensioners and those people on low incomes; it is actually bad for the economy. It destroys jobs. It is a new tax.
The government waxes lyrical at times about how good it would be for the states to abolish payroll tax because it is a tax on employment. They are introducing a new goods and services tax, a value added tax, on the biggest growth employment sector in the economy—the services sector. Labour is the value added in the services sector. The goods and services tax is a massive tax on employment. If you do not believe that, look at what the European Commission has now recom 
 mended to its member states. It has recommended that they experiment with reducing the goods and services tax as a means of generating employment, particularly in the services sector. In other words, they believe that the GST is harmful to employment in the services sector—the very point that we have been making. Also, interestingly enough, they say that it has created a huge new black economy in the services sector, something that this government has argued would be corrected.
The other thing about this budget is that it breaches election commitments. We saw that unctuous Prime Minister get up and say again, hand on heart, `The greatest thing, the proudest moment, I had last night was knowing that we had honoured every election promise.' As soon as he was asked by the member for Batman to justify why he had ditched one, he would not answer the question.
—He would not have the courage.
—He does not have the courage because he has not got the answer. This bloke is a fraud and this budget is a fraud on the Australian people. He went to the last election and said there would be no losers. We have identified the losers and he has done nothing to compensate them—one broken promise to start with. He and the Leader of the National Party of Australia said they would not sell the whole of Telstra, yet this budget says they will—another broken promise. And this was the grandmother of them all today: he told the Australian public, in response to Senator Harradine, that there would be full compensation for the youth allowance and yet the budget does not even half-compensate it. When he was asked the question, he was whispered in the ear by the Treasurer—who by the way set him up again—to say, `We have honoured our commitment to the Australian public.' He did not say that he had honoured his commitment to Senator Harradine. Where does this Prime Minister get off? Isn't a promise given in good faith to whomever something that must be honoured? This Prime Minister does not believe so. So there are huge broken promises in this budget and the Prime Minister's unction just confirms 
 the fact that no-one can believe him when he says he gives his word.
The other interesting thing—and I think this is important because it is a real embarrassment for this government—is that the budget, for all the hoopla that surrounds it, demonstrates you do not need a GST to secure the revenue base. That is what it shows. The contribution to the revenue base will increase by $5.1 billion this year and $9.5 billion over the coming year. In fact, this year the total revenue to GDP is the highest it has been in 10 years and next year it will go higher again, I think, to probably the highest in recent recorded history. This from a system that is supposed to be broke? Give us a break!
The truth of the matter is the system is not broke. One of the great lies that you have perpetrated is that we need tax reform because the current system is not up to it. This budget confirms it is up to it. The truth of the matter is—and this is the point that the Leader of the Opposition has made—the Treasurer still stupidly does not understand that if you did not have your GST you would end up with a bigger surplus. That is the truth, and the reason is that to buy your GST you have dip into the surplus to the tune of $5 billion to $7½ billion just for the tax cuts—forget the states and forget the additional compensation—in your ANTS package.
Do you know where the great bulk of those tax cuts go? To the top 20 per cent of income earners, the high rollers in this nation. This is a budget that wants to slug pensioners and low income earners with a new, insidious tax that is going to destroy jobs, yet it is going to give the great tax breaks to the high rollers and the casino owners in this country. This is a government with priorities so skewed it does not deserve to occupy the benches opposite. We will be doing whatever we can to ensure this GST is defeated, and when it is we will see the real budget. (Time expired)

name: Fahey, John, MP
text:
—While I am delighted to participate in this debate, I spent 15 minutes trying to see what the substance of the matter of public importance was by listening intently to the spokesman on the economy from the opposition and 
 I have to say I am none the wiser. He puts forward a matter of public importance that says we should debate:
The failure of the government's budget to address the real priorities of the nation.
In the 15 minutes from the matter of public importance being brought on I went to the transcript that I got from his interview on the Ray Fewings program on 5DN Adelaide this morning. If you read that transcript, you just simply shake your head and say, `My God, what chance has the opposition got of having any coherent economic policy at any time in the future whilst ever the member for Hotham is their spokesman,' because in that interview he says such things as, `You've got to look below the surface in terms of the surplus; they have not delivered on their promise.' That is the statement this morning. We have not delivered on our promise for a surplus? What seems to be more of concern to the member for Hotham and the Labor Party at the present time is that we actually have achieved a surplus. In fact, they seem to have had this modern day conversion that supports surpluses. Later in the interview he says to Matt Peacock of the ABC, `Let's secure a higher surplus.'
Today, of course, the Treasurer has made it abundantly clear that the party in opposition that believes in surpluses had absolutely no belief in them when they had hold of the purse strings on the treasury bench. They did not know the meaning of surpluses and in their last five budgets they added to general government debt to the tune of $70 billion, to the extent that we as a government have had to pay month after month to the bank the interest on that debt through those deficits which Labor ran up. Yet the member for Hotham and the Labor Party now talk about the virtues of surpluses and say such things, as the member for Hotham did this morning, as, `Let's secure a higher surplus.'
This matter of public importance relates to the budget. Yet for 11 of the 15 minutes all we heard from the member for Hotham was about the tax package, which he referred to as the GST—he said it was deficient—then he went on to talk about the sell-off of Telstra and then, of course, he tried to give some 
 figures on how we will not get our growth because it is too reliant on consumption. The GST, and the component of that tax package that represents the GST, was announced long before the last election. The figuring on that came in the Mid-year economic and fiscal outlook. That was tabled in this parliament after its release in December last year. It is on the record.
It flows throughout the budget papers on this occasion, as it should, because it does have an impact—not in the next year, as again we have had to point out to the opposition today, but commencing on 1 July 2000. It is not relevant to the budget that was delivered by the Treasurer last night other than to the extent of the projections in the forward estimates, which every budget contains. Those opposite say, `The only reason that you are able to get a GST in place is that you are taking the revenue, but we don't need a GST for the revenue.'
We agree with that. We as a government have recognised that all Australians are paying too much direct tax. What we want to do through a new tax package, as has been announced and as has received the support of the Australian people, is to give some of that tax back to Australian taxpayers. We want to give $13 billion a year in tax cuts. We do not want more revenue; we want to give it back to the Australian people. Not only do we want to give $13 billion—we do not want that revenue—but also we are prepared to add to that to the tune of another $2½ billion per year in additional benefits for families. In those areas where there is the need, that new tax system will provide a total of $15½ billion a year in benefits to the Australian people.
Yet we have the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ranting and raving in here today about the only way in which we will get growth is if it is based on consumption. He then proceeds to say that we have a softening on consumption and that all of the revenue and growth is driven by domestic consumption. I would suggest to every member of the House that when we forecast, as the budget papers do, the growth in domestic consumption of 3.75 per cent, that is extremely robust. 
 It is down slightly from the 4.5 per cent that is estimated to be the growth in domestic consumption for the 1998-99 year but it is still very healthy.
The Deputy Leader of the Opposition suggests that we will not have the capacity for further healthy domestic consumption, but I would simply point out to him that, from 1 July 2000, we as the government want to top up the extra $320 per month off disposable income in the pockets of families—the benefits that the lower interest rates delivered under this government have meant to the mortgage payments of those average families—and at the discretion of those families by giving significant tax cuts to those average families. This will give them more flexibility and more discretion to use the funds that they receive with the income and the pay packet that comes in each week. That is what the new tax system delivers.
But it seems to me that the best that Labor can do within the early hours of this particular budget being brought down is, firstly, to ignore the budget and, secondly, to go back to some of those other issues—such as the new tax system which has been done to death. We have had more inquiries and investigations carried out by the Senate than the average state homicide squad over the past few months. None of those inquiries have brought about any conclusion that supports the rhetoric we constantly hear from Labor to suggest that there is not sufficient compensation in the package or that there are losers.
What Labor should do is take some advice on those issues—they are not relevant to the budget but, clearly, Labor do not want to talk about the budget—from some of their own. They should take some advice from Mr Hogg, their former Secretary; they should take some advice from the guru of campaigning in New South Wales, Mr Della Bosca, who was seen to be a dud when it came to the federal election six or seven months ago but who is now a genius when it came to the state election—because they have made it very clear that it is about time Labor got on with it.
The best thing Labor can do—if it is interested in growth, if it is interested in jobs and 
 if it is interested in complimenting the very good work that this government has done for the economy—is to start looking to the future and forgetting about the past. They should support those provisions that are before the Senate at the present time in respect of tax and allow this country to grow at an even greater rate than it has in the past, because that is the opportunity that is there. That opportunity was enhanced by last night's budget.
 The opposition's suggestion that this government wants to take the benefits of the revenue from the GST once again shows its complete ignorance of what the legislation is about, because we do not want that money. We do not want any of the revenue from the GST. The legislation gives all of that revenue to the states. All of the states' premiers and the territories' chief ministers think that it is absolutely fantastic.
When they came down here six or seven weeks ago, I think I heard that Treasurer in New South Wales say on that occasion that the current Prime Minister of Australia has been the best Prime Minister that Australia has had since Ben Chifley.
—Who said this?
—That came from one Michael Egan, the Treasurer of New South Wales, as a result of this package of tax reform that this government is implementing—if we can get the support of the Senate—because Mr Egan knows that all of the revenue of the goods and services tax goes to the states. Mr Egan knows that, for the very first time in this process of Commonwealth and state relations, the states have a growth tax built in. Instead of coming down cap in hand year after year—and God knows I did it for a while—asking and hoping that there is some benevolence in the Prime Minister of the day so that you can go back and start doing some proper plans for your hospitals, your schools and your roads, they are guaranteed all of the goods and services tax. That goods and services tax means that, with the increase over the years, there is growth built in. The states can then make some definite plans for the future to provide those needs that state governments are responsible for.
 We have seen the focus in this debate this afternoon not on the budget—even though that is what the matter of public importance is about—not on the benefits that are in the budget, and there are significant benefits in there, but on the so-called deficiency of the GST that Labor state premiers think is fantastic and on the other issues which relate to legislation before the Senate; namely, the sell-off of Telstra.
Labor say, `The budget is only good if Telstra is sold.' Let me say this: we are not going to spend the money we are getting from the sale of Telstra. Not like Labor who, in the early 1990s, actually threw in the benefits of the Qantas sale in three budgets. They indicated budget after budget after budget that there was some money coming from the sale of Qantas. We know those figures go into the contingency reserve and they cannot be identified; they are mixed up a little for commercial-in-confidence reasons—quite legitimate. But Labor tried it three times.
Each time, having built those figures into that budget bottom line, Labor said, `We're going to bring in a responsible and prudent budget.' We know what happened in those days when those opposite were going about the sale of Qantas: they brought in five successive deficit budgets. Heaven forbid what the true story might have been if they had not kept putting figures from the sale of Telstra in and trying to hide them and putting figures from the sale of Qantas in and trying to hide them.
We know that those opposite did not believe in using the proceeds of an asset sale to retire debt; they used it for current programs and ran up that debt I spoke of a little earlier—$70 billion. We were paying $9½ billion in interest on that $70 billion instead of providing $9½ billion to those in the welfare sector, those needing some requirements in health. I would like to give that money to health, to education, to welfare—the true priorities, the real priorities of the nation, the priorities that have been ignored in the contribution to this debate by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He is not interested in the budget. He would hope, as would all members of the Labor Party, that the great benefits that 
 will flow, the consolidation that will continue, the fiscal responsibility that will continue for the fourth successive year will be forgotten very quickly. Well, it will not. I say that because this morning I addressed 700 people at a breakfast held in the Sydney Town Hall on whom a survey was undertaken. The people were surveyed on how they had reacted to the delivery of the government's budget last night. From the survey passed around the breakfast table, the results of which were collated later, it was found that this government's budget had been endorsed with overwhelming support. And why wouldn't it be?
This is the government that in four consecutive years has not borrowed one net dollar; not one net dollar has it borrowed in four years of managing the national accounts. What we have done in those four years—and this is reflected in this year's budget—is paid off some $24 billion of Labor's debt. As the Treasurer said last night, not only have we addressed debt and, through that process of addressing debt, ensured that those factors, that very good set of conditions all Australians benefit from—low interest rates, low inflation, high growth—continues but we want to go further and get rid of the rest of Labor's debt.
I must say that it is a bit galling to spend years working—although I do enjoy the capacity in which I work very, very much—simply to get rid of the waste and mismanagement of your predecessor. That has been to the forefront of all I have had to do in the context of my portfolio for the past several years. Notwithstanding that, we will accept it for the Australian people; we will pay it off. As the Treasurer said, if we get the opportunity to sell all of Telstra, and we want to do it, we will pay off the residue of Labor's debt by 2002-03. As a nation, Australia then can enter the 21st century in exactly the same fashion as we entered the 20th century—with no debt.
We are not interested in spending and squandering—as did those opposite with their asset sales—when we sell Telstra. We are interested in clearing their debt. That is good for the Australian people, and it is good for 
 the growth that we are experiencing and that we will experience in the future. With the exception of the reference to domestic consumption as being `a little flat'—still robust, I have to say, but a little flat—no other reference has been made about growth. We have good growth in this nation, and it will continue while we are in government. (Time expired)

name: Emerson, Craig, MP
text:
—This budget is living proof of what Labor repeatedly said during the election campaign, and that is that the government does not have a plan for the nation; it has a plan for a tax. Australians are crying out for a plan to reduce unemployment permanently, but in the budget unemployment is stuck at 7½ per cent. I wonder whether the Prime Minister recalls on 18 February this year in this chamber making the comment:
In terms of an individual policy, our top priority is to reduce unemployment.
I wonder whether the Prime Minister can explain why the budget forecast has no reduction in unemployment below 7½ per cent; indeed, why the budget contains no mention of the five per cent unemployment target; why unemployment got a mere five paragraphs on page 8 of the Treasurer's budget speech; and why the government has allocated more in the 1999-2000 financial year for Taxation Office computers to implement the GST than for job creation programs to get unemployed people back to work.
Fleetingly in February of this year, we had bipartisan support for Labor's unemployment target of five per cent—if only because the Treasurer did not want his leadership rival, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, to steal the march on him. I refer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 February 1999 that begins:
The Treasurer, Mr Costello, has held out the prospect of Australia slashing unemployment to near the United States "full employment" level of 4 to 5 per cent.
It goes on to state:
Mr Costello said the GST would boost employment, giving a fiscal stimulus, reducing income tax 
 rates and producing a better balanced tax system which would lead to higher economic growth.
Then on 2 February, the West Australian  reports:
Treasurer Peter Costello said the Federal Government could cut unemployment from 7.5 per cent to less than 5 per cent, but only if the Senate agreed to introduce a goods and services tax.
The budget does contain a goods and services tax, but we have been unable to find any reference anywhere in the budget to the five per cent target. In fact, Treasury expects employment growth over the next three years to slow down and it foresees no improvement in the unemployment rate. This means that the benefits of economic growth are not being shared fairly. I would point out that, compared with Labor over an equivalent period, this government has created less than half as many full-time jobs and only two-thirds as many part-time jobs as Labor. Long-term unemployment has increased to 212,000 since the government began to slash Labor's job programs three years ago.
Where are the jobs in this budget that the Treasurer said would be created by the GST? There are none. Professor Dixon of Monash University in reporting to the Senate GST inquiry described the GST as `job destroying'. Even Mr Murphy, the Prime Minister's preferred modeller, could find no jobs from the GST. For the unemployed and regional Australia, this budget is a budget of despair. It is not a plan for a nation, it is not a plan for jobs; it is a plan for a tax. It is a consumption tax that will affect consumer spending. I point out in the budget documents that very point:
There is also likely to be some net increase in household consumption in the latter part of 1999-2000 ahead of the introduction of the A New Tax System  package.
So the GST will affect consumption. But, interestingly, the budget says that the GST will not affect prices. We are assuming that away. On page 1-11 it states:
The impact on prices of the tax reforms under A New Tax System  is not included in the projections. However, this impact has been taken into account separately in projecting the revenues and expenses affected by the tax reforms. 

So they are going to take the revenues but we are assuming away any impact at all on prices. So they get an inflation figure of 2½ per cent in the year 2000-01. The reality is that Treasury has revealed that the inflationary impact of the GST alone in that year will be at least 3.1 per cent, and it could be more than four per cent if all the indirect tax reductions are not passed through immediately. We know that will be the case. So what we are really looking at is price rises in that year of around 6½ per cent. The government is saying in these documents that it is 2½ per cent.
I would have loved to have been in the cabinet room when this was being discussed. I can see what would have happened. The government would have said, `If we put the true price effect of the cost of living increases from the GST in this budget document, we'll get killed.' Treasury would have said, `Well, you're the ones who put 1.9 per cent out during the election campaign, which is a dodgy figure. You would have to put in 3.1 per cent at least.' The government would have said, `We can't do that, so we'll just assume it away.' In question time today the Treasurer was asked by the shadow Treasurer:
Will you rule out further reducing the surplus in order to bolster the GST compensation and, if not, how much of the surplus are you prepared to spend to increase GST compensation?
It is a pretty straightforward question. The Treasurer replied that we only have one surplus; that is the surplus for the coming year. We only have one surplus in the budget. That's all we've got. I draw your attention again to page 1-3, which projects the surplus figures over three years. I can see what has happened here. The Treasurer has carried the lawyer's brief into the parliament. He has said, `Look, I am not very good at numbers, so just give me one number. What is the surplus this year?' His staff would have given him the number. When the shadow Treasurer asked him about the impact on the surplus in the coming years beyond the first year, he said, `No, we don't have those figures in the budget.' They do have the figures in the budget, but obviously the Treasurer cannot recall those figures. We need to know how much GST compensation is going to be taken 
 off those surplus figures which the Treasurer is saying do not exist in the budget. Clearly they do.
With unemployment stuck at 7½ per cent in this budget, it is timely to remind ourselves of what the five economists have been saying: that is, by economic growth alone we will not get unemployment below 7½ per cent—much or anything below 7½ per cent. What is needed is a comprehensive jobs plan. Labor is advocating a comprehensive jobs plan. It is a plan that involves tax reform without a GST. It involves tax credits. It involves improving the incentives to move from welfare to work. It is a plan that includes active labour market programs. It is a plan most fundamentally that invests in people and ideas.
We can build on a jobs plan on these ideas by investing in the talent of Australia and investing in ideas, by investing in education and in Australia's research and development effort. The Treasurer said on radio today, `Look, you won't get unemployment down if you do nothing.' Well, in the budget unemployment is stuck at 7½ per cent. It is obviously a do-nothing budget. All it does is impose a $32 billion new tax and sell Telstra. It is not a debt reduction strategy; it is a sell Telstra strategy.
We point out that there is a $40 billion undervaluation of Telstra in this budget because of a convenient accounting standard that they are citing—a $40 billion undervaluation that is designed to make the sale of Telstra look attractive. But the sale of Telstra is not attractive. It is clearly better to hold on to Telstra to get the dividends from Telstra and to get the growth in the value of Telstra for the Australian public. It does not make sense to sell Telstra, and they have had to manipulate the figures to try to create a case for selling it.
Again, I would be very interested in the cabinet discussion where the Deputy Prime Minister would have said, `Look, if we are putting all these figures in the budget about the full sale of Telstra, what about my inquiry?' They would have said, `So much for your inquiry. That one is biting the dust.' Obviously he got rolled.
This is a budget that is built  almost totally on consumer spending. It is built on the Bankcard. (Time expired)

name: Bishop, Julie, MP
text:
—I could not resist a double-take when I read the opposition's so-called matter of public importance. It seemed to be such a point of breathtaking hypocrisy for the opposition led by its former Minister for Finance that it was hard to believe the opposition was suggesting that the government's budget had failed to address the real priorities of this nation. I have been in this House for nearly six months now, and I have yet to hear what the opposition considers to be a priority, any priority, let alone a national priority.
But then I appreciated what a golden opportunity I had to pay tribute today to the Howard government, to pay tribute to the Treasurer for his outstanding effort in producing a budget that is reassuring to all Australians in its commitment to sound economic management, that delivers on election promises and that is positively inspirational in its vision for the Australia of the future, with its commitment to education, science and medical research, health, small business and the like.
By any measure, pitted against any key performance indicators, this is an outstanding budget designed to be a true investment in Australia's future. This government's repair of the budget and policy measures have enabled Australia to be one of the fastest growing economies in the world despite the Asian crisis. The opposition talks of national priorities. A priority for the federal government is to manage the economy in good times and bad, responsibly and fairly for the ultimate benefit of all Australians, and we have done that. No less than the Sydney Morning Herald editorial labelled it `Responsible and fair'. `A triumph of a determined focus on economic policy,' it said. `A striking testament to the focus policies of governments taking rational economic decisions.'
What does the opposition know of sound economic management? The Leader of the Opposition professes to be an advocate of budget surpluses, yet he is seemingly incapable of giving any credit to this govern 
 ment's ability to deliver a budget surplus for the third successive year—not just talk about it. The opposition steadfastly ignores the fact that, when we came to office three years ago, we found we had inherited a $10 billion underlying cash deficit.
Members might recall the pattern of deceit over the true status of the Labor deficit, a deceit that became a hallmark of Labor's economic management. They boasted of budget surpluses. Members will recall that at budget time in May 1995 Labor trumpeted that they had brought down a budget surplus. After all, the Leader of the Opposition was the then finance minister, and he says he believes in budget surpluses. But at the mid-year review in December 1995 it was revealed that perhaps it was not such a budget surplus. `Perhaps we will downgrade it a little,' he said.
When this government came to office all was revealed. The 1995 budget was in fact in deficit, had always been in deficit—not just a little—for we inherited a $10 billion deficit. Under Labor the underlying deficit blew out beyond all proportions, notwithstanding public statements by the then finance minister, now Leader of the Opposition, that, `We're operating in surplus and our projections are for surpluses in the future.' Wrong. We were not operating in surplus; we were in deficit. In 1991-92 there was an $11.5 billion deficit; in 1993-94, a $17 billion deficit; in 1994-95, a $13 billion deficit; and in 1995-96, a $10 billion deficit. Members will recall Labor's refusal to release updated budget data during the 1996 election campaign. We all know why: because that data was a damning indictment of Labor's fiscal and monetary policies.
The last term of the Labor government failed the Australian people in ways none had done before. At a time when Australia's fortunes could have been on the rise, when it had everything going for it in terms of the global and regional economic environment, when the economic stars were all in place, Labor failed the people of Australia. We had a $10 billion underlying cash deficit, a serious erosion of Australia's savings, and a huge foreign debt. And don't forget that under Labor over a million people were unem 
 ployed, with the unemployment rate peaking at 11.2 per cent. Deficit and debt—that is how Labor treated the Australian economy. Deficit and debt and deception—a novel three dimensional approach.
I recall an article in the Economist in late 1995 headed `Australia: Lucky or Broke?' as it proceeded to damn Labor's record with the prediction that they were sending the country broke, comparing the downward spiral Labor put us into as akin to the worst times in the Mexican economy. I am not aware of an economic theory or policy that suggests sending a country broke or bankrupt should be a national priority.
The priority this government gave to our economy, to our fiscal position, was to focus on the deficit and to work to implement the necessary changes to bring the budget into surplus. We focused on underlying surpluses, for it is this surplus, before asset sales and loan repayments by the states, that builds our savings, builds our economy and provides an investment in our future.
Labor can make all the hollow promises that it likes, that it would have delivered a bigger surplus, but when it had the chance to deliver it failed to do so. We had our priorities right. In just two years we turned that $10 billion deficit into a $1¼ billion underlying cash surplus. And now, by maintaining a consistently disciplined approach to financial management, the surplus is predicted to grow in both cash and accrual terms to more than $5 billion in 1999-2000. With the budget in surplus the government is saving enough to finance all its investment needs. Indeed, we are actually adding to the pool of savings available to finance private investment. This means more projects, creating more jobs and greater opportunities for Australia, and it can be financed with our own savings instead of foreign debt. Is that not a priority?
We have been reducing the massive debt run up by the Labor Party during its profligate days. You would be forgiven for thinking that Labor was running the economy on a perpetual Visa card—run up the debt and the interest and hope it becomes someone else's problem when the time comes to pay it off. That is 
 what this budget and previous Costello budgets have delivered.
In the last five years before the coalition was elected, Labor ran up Commonwealth debt by nearly $80 billion. We had to find $9 billion just to pay the interest bill. Reducing government debt was and is a national priority. Since 1996 the government has reduced the Commonwealth's net debt by around $24 billion. In 1999-2000 we expect to reduce debt by a further $20.5 billion. That is the largest ever reduction in Commonwealth net debt in a single year. In 1995-96 the Commonwealth general net debt was equal to 19 per cent of GDP. In 1999-2000 that is expected to fall to just 8.2 per cent of GDP. That is a $44¾ billion reduction in net debt in just four years. We have the lowest interest rates in nearly three decades underscoring continued strong growth in spending and an all time low in maintaining low inflation. Since early 1996 inflation has averaged two per cent, compared with five per cent over the previous decade. And we are committed to low inflation as a means of achieving economic and employment growth, which will underwrite better living standards for all Australians.
Budget surpluses and lower debt are essential in these times of international and economic financial volatility. That is why Australia is able to resist the disastrous consequences which occurred in regional economies. After two years of economic growth in excess of four per cent, growth of around three per cent—strengthening over the year to around 3½ per cent in the year 2000—is predicted. That is a remarkable achievement. Our economic growth will remain stronger than that of each of the G7 economies.
Having delivered a responsible and fair budget, with the priorities of a sound economy and a sound economic outlook, we have been able to focus and build on other major priorities for this country. The opposition can whinge and carp and nitpick for as long as it has breath in its collective body, but the fact is that we have focused and we are focusing on broad economic and social objectives that are in the interests of all Australian people, and we can deliver.
This budget fulfils the government's election commitments and provides a comprehensive package of assistance, targeted in the priority areas of employment, education, health and research, families, a safer and fairer community, including in rural and regional Australia. These are the priorities of the people of Australia. These are the priorities we focused upon in the last election. These are the priorities we were voted in to achieve. These are the priorities we will deliver upon with this budget. The Australian newspaper editorial observes that the budget:
. . . has honoured the government's election promises . . . it helps to restore the electorate's faith in politicians and their pledges. The disrespect many people give to our political institutions is being given direct attention.
You get disrespect when you get Labor's recipe of deficit, debt and deceit.
On the employment front, it has been a key priority of this government to expand employment opportunities and we will continue to pursue a wide range of labour market reforms. The work for the dole scheme is having an impact and it will be expanded upon. Funding for indigenous employment initiatives will double. Is that not a national priority?
This budget delivers on the trust again placed in the Howard government by the Australian people last October. The government is delivering on its election promises. The budget builds on the extensive program of reforms embarked upon and our priorities of reforming our ailing tax system and revamping Commonwealth-state financial relations. Our priorities of providing assistance in health, education, training, research, rural and regional Australia, families and small business are the priorities of the Australian people.
This government governs for all Australians and this budget demonstrates for ever more that this government has the credentials, the skills, the foresight and the courage to take Australia into the 21st century.
—Order! This discussion has now concluded.

name: Sercombe, Bob,MP
text:
—On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, I present the committee's report, incorporating dissenting reports, on the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Bill 1998.
Ordered that the report be printed.
—by leave—This particular bill has been dealt with in both the previous parliament and the present parliament by the Corporations and Securities Committee. The committee has received a substantial number of submissions and evidence on the matters that the bill deals with.
In fact, the bill was tabled in the House for the first time in July 1998 and then reintroduced in December 1998 and deals with four substantial matters of corporate reform: firstly, reform with respect to directors' duties and corporate governance; secondly, fund raising; thirdly, takeovers; and fourthly, accounting standards.
The report before the House reflects the work and recommendations of the committee and includes reports from the ALP members of the committee, and also a report from the Australian Democrat member of the committee. On behalf of the committee I would like to acknowledge the detailed and helpful submissions and evidence that were made by a wide variety of organisations and individuals.
All members of the committee strongly support the need for ongoing reform of Australia's corporate regulatory environment. It was a process begun by the former Labor government through its Corporations Law simplification program in 1993 and has been re-badged by the present government as the  Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Bill 1998 . There is general agreement that Australian companies need regulations that meet the changing demands of a competitive global marketplace and enable them to take advantage of innovations in capital raisings.
These considerations of course have to be balanced with the need for the highest levels of investor and shareholder protection and 
 ensuring international confidence in the integrity of Australia's capital markets. The importance of this last point is illustrated by the stock exchange recently estimating that some 4.4 million Australians now hold shares directly, and the great majority of those people in fact are likely to be relatively inexperienced shareholders or first-time shareholders.
It is fair to say that not all members of the committee are convinced that the bill has necessarily struck the appropriate balance between the competing needs in this area. Obviously, when the bill comes before the House these matters will be more fully debated than would be appropriate here. One area where the importance of these balances is so critical is takeovers. The firm of accountants, Ernst and Young, recently produced a report on company mergers and acquisitions that found in 1998 that Australia recorded the highest number ever of acquisitions. Their view was that that takeover activity would continue into this current year.
The bill certainly makes takeovers somewhat easier, if it was adopted in its present form. Against the background where experience shows that many takeovers are not successful or fail to achieve their expectations and, certainly, regularly result in significant job losses and sometimes cuts in investment, there is going to be a need, I think, for a substantial amount of attention in the House to this particular aspect of the legislation and also to ensuring that the appropriate balances are struck in order to protect the interests of minority shareholders.
Similar points, I think, could be made in relation to the proposals in the legislation concerning fundraising and corporate governance. Debates over those issues when the bill comes before the House will certainly focus on the need to ensure that the appropriate and correct balances are achieved and that minority shareholders and small investors are not disadvantaged by the way in which the government's reform program is proceeding. I am confident that the report will assist members of the House in understanding the issues involved, in debating the matters in due course, and ensuring that the appropriate 
 balances are struck. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to this report.
