Leave granted.
—I move:
That the House take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

name: Adams, Dick, MP
text:
—I was talking before question time about the Wool International Privatisation Bill 1999 , about the privatisation of Wool International and about how the government made some terrible mistakes in the freezing of the stockpile and the selling of the stockpile. Part of this bill is to privatise Wool International. It is quite understandable and, in fact, it was what was suggested by the Labor government when they established Wool International in 1993. From my discussion with farmers and wool growers this is far more acceptable. Although it may not be useful in increasing wool prices, at least they will have control over their own situation. They can look to the future and determine where we need to position wool in the marketplace for the longer term.
As I said in a previous speech, the freezing of the stockpile was nonsensical, and the only result I can think of is that it will help those bigger growers and others that may have stockpiles of wool to sell off their own stockpiles and make a few additional dollars at the expense of smaller and non-specialised growers. This is backed up by a press release in February of this year in which ABARE said that in moving to the open market private stockholdings were likely to take an increasingly important role. It goes on to say:
While prices are expected to improve as wool availability declines and overall wool demand improves, a sharp and sustained increase in wool prices as the stockpile runs down is unlikely.
Some of our private wool stockpilers perhaps want to make sure that they get an income from the product before the stockpile is brought back into the market. I do know that 
 the industry had some grave doubts about the freezing of the stockpile, but it is prepared to bite the bullet in order to have privatisation started. During 1997-98 Wool International's objectives and functions under the Wool International Act were to undertake the disposal of the stockpile of wool in a manner which would enhance the value of the wool stockpile as much as possible, having regard to Wool International's obligation to comply with a disposal schedule. This required Wool International to deliver between 90,000 and 350,000 bales per quarter and to deliver the last bale of the stockpile of wool by 31 December 2000.
Wool International is also required to sell the stockpile in a manner that seeks to maximise the value of all wool, to manage the wool stockpile, to buy wool only to the extent necessary to ensure that the sale of the stockpile of wool proceeds according to the disposal schedule, and to prepare and implement a strategy for the management and progressive repayment of the accumulated debt. This made a bit of a mockery of this wool freeze without putting the legislation in place before that freeze.
This current legislation is to move Wool International along the road by allowing growers to control their own destinies. This bill now converts Wool International into a Corporations Law company to be known as WoolStock Australia. This company will have the prime responsibility of selling wool from the stockpile in order to maximise returns to shareholders. Although the principal activity of this new company will be selling the stockpile, up to $3 million will be available to spend on investigating and sponsoring new business ventures. I hope that this will also help the ongoing promotion of new ventures and that it just does not go into several consultants' fees along the way, to mates.
I believe the government made a big mistake with the freeze, as I have said before, and that we could have sold more wool by now. I believe that we could have sold 300,000 to 500,000 more bales and that they would have been absorbed by the market if we had not had a freeze and we had found 
 some inventive ways of selling, particularly in a market downturn.
We should be looking at a long-term industry plan and encouraging farmers to take more notice of what happens to their wool. I have said this on a number of occasions before. The farmer needs to understand what is going on beyond the farm gate. We have many new and well-trained farmers now in Australia and they are getting wiser to market trends, but the government should be helping them to make the right and proper decisions. I have a wool grower in my electorate who believes that, if the stockpile was still on the farm—if farmers still had it in their woolsheds so that every time they walked past it they could see the wool sitting there—they would have a different approach to the marketing of wool. They would understand that you need to have a market before you grow something and that just stockpiling it is not an answer. If this is a question of helping Wool International to be the main research organisation for the industry, then that is what should be going on and what we should be doing.
It is recognised now by many observers that the Australian wool industry has experienced one of its most testing and turbulent periods—probably one of its toughest times in the history of this industry. Everybody has their own idea of how to fix it and get the problem solved—which, of course, leads to a lot of mixed messages going out generally. In an article in Outlook 99 earlier this year, a processor described his views of the market. I found these very interesting. He looked at what he sees as the problem with wool. He believes that it is not seen as glamorous and indispensable any more, and he believes that is why the demand for wool and the acceptance of wool has waned. The price of wool has dropped and the cost of producing the wool has increased, so there are no longer any margins for wool growing. Many growers are abandoning the industry. On top of this, you have cheap labour in developing countries, particularly in China, producing export goods which have had a huge effect on international wool markets—that is, other products are being produced from wool because of that cheap labour. So, having identified the main 
 parts of the problem, the processor, Mr John Mitchell, looked at some solutions.
He lands, I believe rightly, on the necessity to promote the product, and to promote it to the right people. Even as far back as my first speech in this House, I was talking about promoting our wool in the same way as other countries do—using a brand and style such as I saw in the Shetland Islands with Harris tweed and Dublin worsted. The wool was not great there, but the promotion of those products was brilliant. Everybody who was anybody had to wear their local product. It was part of their culture and part, of course, of the tourist mystique to buy those products.
Mitchell says that we should be targeting designers and garment manufacturers. Yes, that is what we should be doing. We should be doing that in a great way—we should be right up to our necks in doing that. I would go a few steps further and talk to furniture, fabric, upholstery and carpet designers—as well as any other users in our domestic and our commercial life.
I believe I can start a shortage of wool if we can get our Tasmanian tartan up and running. There is a promotion going with that in Tasmania. Hopefully, this tartan can be a marketing tool not only for our state but also for our fine products and our superfine wool. Wool is also well used in Tasmania for things like doonas, padded coats and pillows—for anything that requires a stable and light padding at the bottom end of the market. Wool might be able to be used for insulation, being a low flammable and well aerated product.
Invent, experiment and try out what wool is good for and then promote, promote, promote. Get in there and promote the product; that is what we have to do. The people who are making something out of wool are those who have diversified their interests and started to look into design and downstream processing. Two small examples I can boast of in Tasmania are Casaveen and Laincot, who are actually experimenting with design and manufacture. They are only small, but they are in there producing things and they are in the marketplace. However, as Mitchell also says, there is a question of who will fund 
 the efforts of promotion. Perhaps this could be by an export levy, or a levy across the whole industry in differing amounts, and depending on where the interest is in the chain towards the sale.
The other point made in the article that I also think is sound is that we must learn as an industry to stop considering man-made fibres as the enemy and our greatest competition. I would suggest that, if a cooperative approach was made, it would be the opposite. It could be the answer and it would help widen the scope and expand the use of both fibres.
Wool is also still seen as something that you knit with. Its woven and fabric uses are hidden to the general public. It is important that those who are promoting it move it away from that knitting image. It is one of the strongest and most versatile and inventive materials anyone could work with, and those who have an interest in and a flair for design will be able to think up a whole range of new products using wool.
I am not sure this new bill is going to provide the necessary incentives or assistance to take the industry into the next century, or to help it be inventive and keen to develop the new products that are necessary. At least the producers will be able to help mould the direction of this company. But, if the government was really being innovative and really wanted to help this industry—which has been in this country since it began—they would be there with a plan and innovative ideas and they would be helping to promote those ideas and that innovation. But of course they are not.
They really have not looked at the future need for wool and the wool industry, and they have not got there yet. It will probably take them a considerable amount of time to get there. I have not heard anyone on the other side speak about where wool is going to be in the future, and that is what has to happen—people have to start looking at and thinking and speaking about it.
The industry needs to consider new technology to change the appearance of wool, to make it more user friendly and appealing. It might involve the addition of new processes and techniques which change wool's perform 
 ance, or at least change people's perception of its properties, which are already very wide. Wool is an exciting fibre. We should not have got to this end where we are looking backwards at wool's past successes. The government has failed to see its potential and has been too busy hiding from possible attackers rather than going out and aggressively marketing our woolly gold.
It is still one of our big potential exporters, and we should be marketing it for all it is worth. We on this side of parliament are disappointed that the government took so long to sort out what it was doing. It set sales back for years because of the silly freeze, the dumb mistake, made by that side of the House, made by the lawyers and the stockbrokers of the Liberal Party against the National Party.
—What a load of absolute rubbish!
—People like the member for Wannon—from the Western District of Victoria—could not get his view up. He got rolled, I understand, with his view.
—Wrong.
—I thought he was on this side. He seems to be indicating otherwise, so he actually was a part of making the wrong decision. I understand that the Deputy Leader of the National Party was knocked over on it, and most of the National Party members again failed to win the day.
We hope that there will be a lot more support for the future wool industry. I think some entrepreneurial flair for the future will come out of the industry itself and that that will be the direction for the wool industry. We on this side of the House hope that the government might get its act together and might start assisting the wool industry to go down the track of starting to look into the future and building itself a very strong and positive future.

name: Hawker, David, MP
text:
—In joining this debate on the Wool International Privatisation Bill 1999 , I listened to the member for Lyons with some interest, but I ended up a bit confused. I thought his final point is exactly what the government is trying to do, but the problem the wool industry has 
 had for too long is too much assistance from government, too much involvement of government and too much interference.
This bill is all about reducing that and allowing the wool industry to become a commercial business. While this bill is dealing with only one aspect of the wool industry, it is a very positive step forward by the government. I am a little disappointed to hear the opposition, while it is not opposing this bill, sounding rather lukewarm and using somewhat confused logic when talking about what the bill really stands for.
It is interesting to note that exactly six months ago we were debating another wool international amendment bill. In that debate I did highlight some of the great errors that the Labor government had made in the past, and that is why I was curious to hear the member for Lyons trying to criticise the government on recent developments and clearly overlooking what happened in the late 1980s.
In that debate I also pointed out with some supporting graphs that, when the government first announced its freeze, we did in fact see the price of wool improve. It is true that an election intervened and the government's proposals were delayed somewhat but, when it was clear that the coalition government had been re-elected, we made it clear yet again that we would be proceeding with that freeze, and again the market recovered. That shows very clearly that the government, far from making a mistake in the freeze, got it absolutely right. It is not a question of saying that those with a private stockpile are benefiting; it is actually those who are growing wool who are benefiting. Those with a private stockpile are a relatively small part of the equation. It is the wool growers, about whom the member for Lyons professes to be concerned, who are the direct beneficiaries of what the government has done.
As I pointed out in that speech, it is a very important development and it is all about allowing the stockpile to be turned into an asset. I am proud to be part of a government that has taken this vital step forward in assisting wool growers and the wool industry to start moving down the path to recovery. As 
 previous speakers have mentioned, wool growers have faced a fairly difficult few years since the collapse of the floor price scheme early in 1991. I join with my colleague the member for Mallee in some of the comments he made earlier. As a wool grower myself, I am acutely aware of what those last few years since 1991 have really meant.
I noticed that the member for Corio also made some rather strange and conflicting comments when he talked about the freeze not being a rational commercial decision. As I have already indicated, there is very clear market evidence to show that it was a commercial decision. As has been pointed out on a number of occasions, a relatively small increase in the price of wool more than offsets any loss in revenue from the stockpile sales and from the cost of holding that stockpile over the seven or eight months the freeze has been in effect.
It is very easy to sit there and look at things in isolation and say that this might be costing money, but to growers it is the price of wool that they are selling on the market today that is the important issue. Contrary to what the member for Lyons was trying to say about an inventive way of selling wool in a down market, Wool International has been trying to do that for eight years and has not yet found it. There are some capable people there, and I think it is a good indication that you just cannot defy the market.
This is all about taking the stockpile and turning it into a commercial asset. That is not meant in any way to decry the effort of Wool International in their management of the stockpile. Given the constraints they had and the objectives they were given, I think they have done a sterling job. The fact is that they were acting as a receiver, and they had to therefore work with those sorts of constraints.
I commend the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee for their work in looking at this legislation. While I appreciate that their report has not yet been finalised, it is interesting to look at some of the submissions they received, and I will go into a couple of those in a bit of detail.
Many wool growers and people in the wool industry see this legislation as part of this 
 government's very significant move to give wool growers and the wool industry a chance to recover. There is no doubt that the last few years have been extremely difficult, and I think this government has shown real initiative and real leadership in what we have done—firstly, with the stockpile and, secondly, with setting up the wool industry task force, headed by the former Minister for Defence, Mr Ian McLachlan. I have no doubt, subject to one qualification, they will make some very worthwhile recommendations.
It is very important to note what can and cannot be expected from this legislation and the move to form Wool International into a new company, WoolStock Australia. The submission that came from Mr Don McGauchie, the Chairman of the Wool Interim Advisory Board, sets out very clearly what this legislation is all about, and it also probably dispels some of the misunderstandings that are around. For example, as he pointed out, as of 31 December last year, the stockpile was 1,055,000 bales and was valued at around $656 million. The accumulated debt was $179 million and the net value of the stockpile was therefore, at 31 December, $470 million, or approximately $1.35 per unit of equity. So growers who contributed between 1993 and 1996 stand to get that back as shares in the form that has been detailed in the legislation. There are 349,403,135 units registered against 91,841 unit holders.
The Wool Interim Advisory Board has been consulting widely and meetings have been held in all states where there is a major wool growing interest. The points that Mr McGauchie summarised from those consultations are important to note. A number of them are:
The processors and traders generally supported the commercial arrangements to sell stockpile wool . . . 
. . .              . . .             . . .
Most of the growers were comfortable with the privatisation of Wool International.
. . .              . . .             . . .
The concern expressed about any discounting of the stockpile wool price adversely impacting on the sale of fresh wool was responded to by explaining the objective of the new entity would be to maxi 
 mise the value of the return from stockpile wool and any downward pressure exerted on the fresh wool price would devalue the stockpile and not be in the interest of shareholders.
That is a very important point. It shows the difference that the new board will be able to exercise to their commercial approach that the previous board, Wool International, were unable to because of the legislative constraints that were placed on them in various forms during their lifetime.
The Office of Asset Sales also made some very pertinent points in their submission to the Senate committee. They pointed out that this is an extremely professional approach to privatisation, and the fact that they have employed both Deutsche Bank and Blake Dawson Waldon to advise on legal matters shows that they have certainly taken their job very seriously. In their submission, they talk about protecting the rights of unit holders and they say:
The unit holders' existing entitlements against WI will be preserved and the obligations to distribute surpluses to unit holders will be retained.
As they say:
The structure proposed preserves the rights of the unit holders and thus manages the risk that their constitutional rights have not been adequately addressed.
They point out that they have addressed that point. Another point of importance to note is the taxation treatment. In the submission, they state:
1.	 WSA will be tax exempt in relation to stockpile activities;
2.	 Primary Production Income tax status continues in respect of distributions to eligible unit holders; and
3.	 Small Business Capital Gains tax roll-over relief continues in respect of eligible unit holders.
In other words, the government has shown that it is sympathetic towards the plight of the wool growers by recognising that the proceeds from the sale of the stockpile can be rolled back into the farming business.
Another point that has caused some concern is the number of unit holders who have not been fully identified. In fact, it has been suggested that the figure is around 26 per cent. But the qualification of that is that 
 roughly 25 per cent of that 26 per cent are identifiable but not in a legally binding name. For example, K. Smith would not be acceptable, but Kevin Smith would be. So approximately one per cent of the unit holders cannot be identified because either the address is unknown or, in some cases, it is a false address.
It is important that we recognise that the opportunity will be there and must be exercised for growers, who in most cases will have already received some repayments when previous distribution was made from Wool International, to respond to the letter that will be coming in the mail shortly. This is to make sure their legal status is properly clarified so that they will have the opportunity to exercise their vote when the first general meeting of shareholders is held. I expect it to be some time in late August this year. So when they receive that letter they should respond to make sure that they are legally entitled to vote.
I want to make a couple of other points. I congratulate Don McGauchie and his interim board on the very professional job that they have done with fairly tight time constraints to get this up and running. I believe that because of the very professional approach that has been taken we will see this whole body move smoothly. I think it is also important to note that three of the new directors will be up for election at that first meeting. It is important that growers take ownership of this new entity, WoolStock Australia, as quickly as can be arranged. It is also interesting to note that Mr McGauchie, in his appearance before the committee, pointed out the following:
. . . we have had some quite encouraging correspondence from, and discussions with, the Australian Stock Exchange. Whilst not being a fully listed company, at least the Stock Exchange is looking to conduct a market for shares in this business. That would give anyone an opportunity to stand in the market and buy shares rather than try to buy the wool, if someone wished to do that. Likewise, in relation to anyone wishing to make an offer for the entire stockpile, once the new board is appointed it will start to lay out a process for that.
Again, that is very important given the interest that has been shown in it. I mentioned something about the wool task force. I was 
 extremely concerned to read a report in the Age  last Monday, in the business section, headed up `Huge wool grower exodus tipped'. The opening statement read:
Half of Australia's 46,000 wool growers will be wiped out in five years by the reforms necessary to make the industry competitive, according to a leading wool industry figure.
It went on to say:
A member of the Federal Government's wool industry Future Directions Taskforce, who did not wish to be named, told The Age  that most Australian wool farms were too small to be profitable.
I find that quite staggering and extremely disappointing. For a task force charged with looking to find a profitable future for wool growing to turn around and say that within five years half the people involved in it today are going to be wiped out is extremely negative, discouraging and, I would have thought, quite out of kilter with what should be expected from such a task force. There may be cases to demonstrate that a lot of so-called wool growers are not in fact full-time wool growers. In many cases that is because either they are in mixed farming or wool is a by-product of meat. If we look at the number of full-time wool growers, we may well find that those who are still in wool growing are not necessarily the smallest operators in terms of their flock size because they may not have any other enterprises on their properties or their farms. It disappoints me to see such reports. I would have expected something different. Maybe it is a softening up process for something better. Still, I do not expect the task force should be running those sorts of stories in the media at this stage.
Another point I would like to touch on is that, while wool growers have been facing difficult times, we have also seen some very positive initiatives that have been developed by wool growers in consultation with, in some cases, state governments and state departments. In Victoria's case, the Department of National Resources and Environment has been looking at ways of improving productivity on farm. I think this does recognise that wool growing has not seen the productivity gains that some other farming enterprises have seen. For example, we have seen some quite dra 
 matic improvements in productivity in the dairy industry.
I would like to mention Bestwool 2010, which I think is a very positive program and is certainly being received very enthusiastically in many parts of Victoria, particularly in western Victoria where I come from. It is all about getting farmers to adopt new technology and to use the sort of group psychology that dairy farmers have used so successfully in programs like Target 10 whereby, through a friendly competition type of approach, they lifted their productivity, lifted their output and made themselves into some of the best farmers in the world. This approach, which has been adopted for some time but has been extended to the wool industry, is very positive and something we should all be encouraging.
Privatising the stockpile is indeed a very important step that the government is taking. I think we can demonstrate that the decision for, first of all, the freeze with the intention of privatising on 1 July was the correct one. It does make a significant step forward for the wool industry. It will turn this stockpile, which has been such a dampener on the market for so many years, from being a liability to being an asset. It will also unleash the commercial powers that will make this industry so much stronger and help to regain so much of the ground that wool has lost in recent years. At the same time, I also recognise that this is only part of the program this government is taking to ensure that growers can go into the next century in a much stronger and more healthy position.
 I commend the minister, Mark Vaile, for the very positive approach he has taken to the wool industry. I believe that it will be for the benefit of the wool industry and also obviously for the benefit of Australia. I think it should also be remembered that wool, while it may not have had the best of fortunes in recent years, is still one of the biggest primary industries in Australia. It is still one of the big export earners with earnings of around $4 billion a year. That is down quite a bit on what it was 10 years ago, but there is no reason why, with the right approach, we could not see the wool industry regain some of the lost ground and improve its output. Already 
 in the way wool growers are approaching the task there is every reason to be optimistic about this, and the work the government is doing is showing real leadership in this area.

name: Andren, Peter, MP
text:
—In considering the ramifications of this move to get government out of the wool industry, it is interesting to cast one's eyes back over other debates at other times concerning the wool industry. It has been the subject of passionate debate throughout the first 99 years since Federation, and the argument over the advantages of a free or a controlled market for wool is not confined to recent years. Indeed, 48 years ago the Australian parliament was debating the wool contributory charges bills which, among other things, repealed the levy on wool sold in Australia. The levy had been introduced a year earlier, in 1950, and had yielded £45 million, a staggering amount by any standards. But, after a referendum of growers on the proposed reserve price was overwhelmingly voted against, the government introduced legislation to repay that money. The referendum result had come as a shock to both the government and the opposition of the day, with the then Labor member for Lalor commenting that his only regret was the fact that `the wool growers had so little confidence in the plan they kicked it ignominiously out the door'. I wonder if things have changed much in intervening years with government and the so-called industry leaders meddling in the wool industry and growers treating with deep scepticism most moves to improve the lot of the industry.
Growers have seen governments and the so-called industry leaders in recent years sending a series of contradictory messages to world markets—markets that have exploited this uncertainty by forcing our growers to compete against themselves by virtue of the stockpile. It was for this reason that, after consulting many growers in my immediate area and beyond, I supported the freeze. There was not universal support amongst the growers, as everybody knows, but there was a recognition that there needed to be some pause to consider just what role the stockpile was playing in the marketplace. I and others firmly believe that it was an impediment to a market. In fact, 
 many growers recognised that their own product was competing against them in the very market in which they were hoping to derive some reasonable returns from their newer clips.
As we debate the  Wool International Privatisation Bill 1999  and, hopefully, move towards the wool producers taking more charge and responsibility from yard to yarn, it is again sobering to note some other comments from that wool bill debate in 1951 when the then member for Riverina pointed out to the House how, in 1936, it had been necessary to establish a fund to promote wool. Why was this necessary? As the honourable member said:
At that time the industry was said to be threatened by synthetics and all sorts of other dubious materials that were on the market. In fact, some of our best informed economists imagined that the end of the wool industry was in sight and never again would be a profitable industry. They prophesied that synthetics would obliterate it.
The same debate detailed how the wool acquisition scheme of World War II resulted in an accumulation of 10 million bales. It was thought it might take between 15 and 20 years to get rid of that stockpile. Some growers sold their merinos in anticipation of a prolonged glut, but it took but a fraction of that time to sell the wool. Oh, that the world was so hungry for the product today when one million bales still pose a major marketplace hurdle. One must remember the roller-coaster ride wool had after World War II, with the pound a pound days of the Korean War replaced by despair not so many years later, climaxing in the 106c a kilo days of the early seventies.
From that point on, there is a litany of examples of government stuff-ups that helped erode wool's share of the world fibre market, irrespective of the increasing improvement in other man-made fibre. As one producer in my electorate told me, virtually everything the government did could not have been better designed to maximise the losses, both financial and social, to Australia's wool growers. The producer, Ted O'Brien from Bylong, believes that, ever since the government hijacked the management of wool marketing, there has been no real talk of developing new 
 markets for wool beyond fiddling around the edges of existing markets. Some might not agree with Ted when he says the present government's determination to dump the stockpile no matter what has caused more injury to people in the industry than the decisions of the Hawke government. But, whoever were the worst managers, it is agreed the industry itself, given the right circumstances and personnel, will make a better fist of marketing wool than government or quasi-governmental bodies have done in the past.
But it is sobering to note the comments of NFF President, Ian Donges, who sees the process set in train by this bill as `reincarnating' Wool International. The intention of this bill should, of course, be to try to reincarnate the stockpile as an asset rather than as a burden. Thousands of farmer shareholders will now theoretically be responsible for disposal of this asset. I say `theoretically', because up to 40 per cent of the shares in Wool International are yet to be allocated and will be held by a trustee company. We do not yet know who will hold the voting rights for this trustee company. We do know that such a voting block has enormous potential to vote in a way not in the interests of those growers and shareholders who are out there active in the industry—actually growing wool, not speculating with it. There are other concerns with some growers questioning the structure of WoolStock Australia Ltd. What will be the motives of any trustee company vote? Short-term gain or long-term stability?
There are growers in the industry who question why the government says it wants out of management of the stockpile and yet is controlling the appointment of board members. There is concern about the government's appointment of the first three directors who, in turn, appoint the rest of the board. This does not suggest to me a government getting out of the wool industry. However, I acknowledge the difficulties of establishing a board in the short term. I trust this arrangement will be temporary and shareholders will have a full and open opportunity to elect their own board not too far down the track. Board Chairman Donald McGauchie has made assurances the 
 new company will indeed be a short-term operation, and that he is not settling in for the long term in, as Ian Donges puts it, a `reincarnation of Wool International'.
The establishment of WoolStock Australia is but one step in the recovery of the Australian wool industry. The other vital process is that being conducted by the wool industry Future Directions Taskforce, charged with looking at a strategic path for the industry, a benchmarking of wool against its competitors, and reviews of wool marketing and promotion and structures for wool research and development. This process is going to be difficult, given the variety of views around the nation about what to do with our wool industry.
But I know the growers in my area are frustrated at the lack of input they have had with the process that decides how and where their product ends up. Might I refer the House to comments from the head of the ANZ Agribusiness Advisory Unit, Bruce Brown, in the February issue of Australian Farm Journal. In that, he published a table showing how much it cost to sell Australia's wool and the complicated process to get the product to market. He says, in part:
. . . the wool industry seems to spend more time hankering after its glorious past rather than making significant united efforts to revitalise and restructure a convoluted and cost plus handling distribution and processing chain that is incapable of delivering accurate information flows up and down the chain.
That is the message I am hearing from concerned growers in my electorate. They feel they have had no part in the process over the years and they now feel it is time for them to take charge. Among many important points Mr Brown makes is the need for cost savings. I agree that core sampling, electronic selling and the movement of wool direct from farm to the wool dump and container would provide significant cost savings and, as Mr Brown says, `a pipeline similar to cotton'. However, he also points out—and this is the concern of growers I have spoken with—that attempts will be made, by entities with vested interests, to frustrate such reforms. Those vested interests with an unnecessary finger in the pie are part of wool's problems. I only hope the Future Directions Taskforce and the 
 new WoolStock Australia are up to the job and are not captive to the same vested interests that have hampered the industry for so long.
I have had several talks with Mr Edward Jones, a former marketing director and CEO of Fortuna Fabrics, a man who has developed markets in the textile industry all over the world and who was making commercial deals with China as long ago as 1968. Mr Jones, who lives in my electorate, was the author of the Jumbuck Paper, as a result of his concerns over meat marketing in the 1980s, and later became chairman of Tendapak Technologies. Mr Jones is also a former merino producer who now specialises in growing first-cross ewes. Mr Jones believes a total marketing strategy is needed for the wool industry. He believes the first essential is to deal with the stockpile and he has creative ideas about how the stockpile should be marketed. He believes the industry requires not wool specialists but commercial specialists who can market wool as a desirable and necessary product.
Talking of the historical problems with marketing takes me back to some comments I made in the Wool International Amendment Bill debate back in November. I quoted George Gibbons, the Labor member for Calare who was elected for one term in 1929—I am pleased to say I have passed his record of one term—who said:
The breeding of distinct types of sheep and the improvement of wool quality are essential if we are to maintain the high prices now obtainable for our wool—
that is, at that time—
despite the unscientific methods of marketing it.
As Mr Jones says, unscientific methods of marketing wool have plagued this industry for too long. He has discussed what I believe are some quite exciting ideas about marketing wool and also marketing the stockpile. He has offered to meet the task force with a view to outlining those not insubstantial suggestions for a proper marketing strategy. He has a strong marketing background, a strong interest in the industry and also a strong background in the meat industry. However, the chairman of the task force, Mr Ian McLachlan, has not yet seen his way clear to inviting Mr Jones to 
 present his ideas to the task force. Mr McLachlan wants Mr Jones to spell out his ideas in writing before he is considered for a guernsey. Mr Jones quite rightly wants to protect the commercial confidence of some of his ideas. Because of his track record in the meat and textile industries, I think his request warrants more considerate treatment than he has received to date. I only hope the task force looks for and listens to as wide a range of experience as possible and, importantly, experience outside the existing wool industry, because largely that industry has not got it right, along with government meddling over many years.
The market for wool has changed enormously since the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s. We need far more creative marketing strategies to make people want wool. For too long it seems there has been a feeling that all will be well, that wool will re-establish its rightful place in the market. But times have changed, tastes have changed; markets have changed dramatically. There are no Soviet bloc or Chinese armies on the march, thank God. Nor is there a God-given place for wool in world markets anymore. Growers want more say in their industry from now on. But they also want government to put in place those necessary mechanisms to support the industry and, where necessary, help inefficient growers withdraw from the industry. They expect leadership on issues like disease control. This government has been dragged reluctantly into the Johne's disease control program and, despite the budget allocations, it seems government procrastination—both state and federal—over 20 years has seriously delayed a concerted attack on this disease which is causing so much distress in the industry.
There has been a selfish producer element within the industry on this issue that has refused to acknowledge the seriousness of the disease—or perhaps wanted to hide its seriousness—to protect their flocks and income at the expense of the industry as a whole. It is imperative that government continue to support and encourage every endeavour by the wool industry to tackle the challenges ahead. There have been major troughs and 
 peaks in the past, and I am hopeful we are finally on the path to getting it right.
Any member who has kept in touch with his wool growing constituency will know the passion these producers have for their product. We all know what a quality product wool is. We also know just how much our rural communities still depend on wool, and the flow-on impact it has through the towns, the rural suppliers, the transport industry and so on.
Normally I would not be optimistic about wool's chances in a current world market dominated by `all sorts of other dubious materials' as the then member for Riverina said in that debate way back in 1951. However, wool's competition today is not from dubious but from high quality materials, and it is a very serious challenge. But, because it is the wool growing community, I am confident the ingenuity of wool growers in both seeking niche markets and in finding ways to promote their product through closer involvement in the marketing process will win through. This bill will hopefully begin that process if it truly allows the producers to become genuine players in the marketing pipeline. With the reservations I have outlined, I commend the bill to the house.

name: Nairn, Gary, MP
text:
—The Monaro region of my electorate produces some of the best fine wool in the world. It also produces some of the best breeding stock in the country. Even with the horrendous drought the Monaro has seen over the past five years, the region has been able to maintain its high quality. Somehow the wool growers of the Monaro win the many battles put up against them. Whether it be the drought, low wool prices or state government legislation restricting their control of their land, they find a way through it.
When the floor price of wool literally went through the floor, one wool growing family in the Monaro, Peter and Clare Smith, did something different. Instead of adding their wool to the stockpile, they made jumpers and other wool products. That company is Toorallie Wool and now has a number of shops right throughout Australia and overseas, including New Zealand and America.
But many of the Monaro wool growers continued to add their wool to the stockpile. I have many constituents who have a vested interest in the stockpile. Therefore, I have a vested interest myself in the  Wool International Privatisation Bill 1999  which will effectively privatise the stockpile. It is legislation to give back to the rightful owners of the stockpile their asset. It will be their asset to determine what happens to it. They can decide. Why should government be there making decisions on their behalf? It is right and proper for the people who have the real investment in the stockpile to make the decisions about its disposal. That is what this legislation is all about.
It has come about as a result of dissatisfaction by the wool growers in how their industry was being run. Without going back over old ground, suffice to say the wool growers expressed their anger and dissatisfaction by voting out the board who had been acting on their behalf. As a consequence of that action, the federal government set up the McGauchie committee to look at the future of the stockpile and the McLachlan committee to look at the future of the industry, in particular the promotion and marketing of it.
The Wool International Privatisation Bill 1999 is the result of the McGauchie committee's work. I believe it is the correct result. I know that some people in the industry in my electorate were not happy when the government last year froze sales from the stockpile. But it was a contentious issue, because it seemed that no matter who you asked you got a differing view. While many wool growers were very happy with the decision that we made in relation to the freezing of the stockpile, there was also a number of people who were not happy.
I remember being at a function in Nimmitabel—right in the middle of the Monaro—one night shortly after we made that decision. I was sitting talking with a wool grower who is also in the broking area, and he was telling me that it was a wrong decision and that we should not have frozen the stockpile at that time. I said, `Well, I disagree with you. I think it is the right thing to do.' As I was debating the point with him, another wool 
 grower walked behind me, patted me on the back and said, `Great decision that was that your government made in freezing the stockpile.' I stopped and said, `That says it all.' That was really the case.
There were differing views, but I think the overwhelming view at the end of the day was that it was a right decision. We succeeded in achieving what we thought it would do—that is, stabilise the price of wool and move it up. I am not normally one who would support the interference of the government in the market with those sorts of things. But in this particular case I sat back and thought: the wool stockpile is a major asset. It is really no different from any other private organisation that has a product on the market. At any particular time the market is not going all that well, there is an oversupply, and therefore it is not unusual for a private organisation to hold back supply at various times until the market price improves. That is the normal way in which the free market works. I believe that, in doing that with the stockpile, we had some effect on the price. The initial reaction was a price rise, then there was a steadying, with some rises and falls since then, but certainly we are in a better position than we were before the stockpile was frozen.
Having gone through all of that, the government needed to make a definitive decision about the asset—that is, the stockpile. We were firmly of the view that, at the end of the day, the wool growers themselves had to make those decisions. Wool growers who have paid into that stockpile will become the shareholders. Each existing registered equity holder will receive one share in WoolStock Australia Ltd for each unit held by them. Basically, the existing Wool International will be privatised and the private entity of WoolStock Australia Ltd will own the asset. WoolStock Australia will be exempt from income tax on any amounts received from sales of stockpile wool and incidental activities in connection with selling the stockpile wool and distribution of the proceeds. That is a very important aspect and, I think, a useful provision that has been put into this legislation; it is certainly something that wool 
 growers in my area were extremely happy about.
Another part of the structure is for the establishment of a trust company which will hold the units of persons and shares of members who cannot, for a number of reasons, have their units and/or their shares transferred to them. There has been some criticism of this measure by some commentators. However, the numbers that will come into that category within the trust account have diminished in recent times. I would suggest that, as we get closer to a meeting of the shareholders, many more of those unknown people will be identified. I think they will come out of the woodwork and be there as shareholders in their own right as we get closer and closer to this.
Donald McGauchie has been appointed chairman of the new company, with Reg Clairs and Mr Van Rooyan as directors. These appointments have been made by government to allow the company to get under way. Additional directors will be elected by the shareholders ultimately in the normal commercial way. A meeting of shareholders will have to take place within three months of the formation of the new company, which effectively will be 1 July this year.
One of the concerns of many wool growers is that WoolStock Australia Ltd will simply be Wool International mark II. As I came in the chamber to join in this debate, I heard the member for Calare also make the point that a number of people have raised that issue. I can understand the concerns of wool growers in that respect. They really have not been happy with the structure that has been there. I think there have been people looking after certain vested interests. Certainly, I recognise those concerns completely.
I know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in another capacity you have worked with me and others of the government to get to this point with this legislation, and the government has a real commitment to ensuring that we do not end up with Wool International mark II. We know only too well that, if we did end up with that type of result, it would not be healthy for the confidence of the industry. I think at this point in time we have to ensure that there is 
 that strong confidence from the industry about where it goes from here.
I have certainly assured wool growers in my electorate that we will not allow there to be such an outcome. I have expressed that assurance to wool growers such as John King, President of Region 11 of the New South Wales Farmers Federation in my area, and other wool growers like Sid Walters down at Dalgety. I know what they have endured, and I want to make sure that they have the best possible opportunity to have real control over their asset.
One of the other matters of contention has been the issue of whether the stockpile should be sold holus-bolus. Some people felt that the McGauchie committee should have been able to make such a recommendation to government. While I strongly believe that anyone interested in purchasing the entire stockpile should be given every opportunity to put their offer, I do not believe that it is the right of government to consider and possibly accept any such offer. That is clearly a decision for the shareholders, the wool growers.
I know that there are a couple of potential buyers who have been working very hard on quite legitimate offers. One of those is Keith Campbell who himself was a wool grower along with his wife Sophie in the Bombala district in my electorate; another is a group led by David Sasson. I know that Keith is very keen to put an offer to wool growers. He has put together very broad expertise, including banking and processing people, and has been working for some time on such an offer. I am not aware of some of the details of the other group, but I am sure, equally so, that an enormous amount of work has gone into their offer. Certainly market research has been done, people have been talking with overseas processors, bankers, accountants, et cetera.
At the end of the day, I would want to see all of those offers being given every opportunity. I know that Keith is particularly keen to put that offer to wool growers. When we get further through this with the legislation being passed, I hope that will be the case. Certainly I hope that the interim board of WoolStock Australia will assist. The McGauchie committee, as it currently is, has 
 access to a lot of information—a lot of due diligence I think has already been given to this matter—but I hope that whatever information they can legally make available to those various groups putting offers together is made available to them, because I would not like to see this go on for a long, long time. Whatever assistance can be given early on will certainly allow the process to continue a lot faster at a later time. I also hope that the board allows any ensuing offers, the ones that do come forward, to be put forward to the shareholders as soon as possible after the company's formation. The wool growers then can decide whether they should accept an offer or whether they should continue to dispose of the stockpile in other ways. That action is for them to decide.
There is one other point regarding that decision. There was concern that legislation would call for a 75 per cent vote in those sorts of circumstances. It was a strong rumour that was running around in the development of the legislation. I do not know where it came from. I know that the government and the wool subcommittee on the government side always saw that it should operate under normal commercial terms—that is, 50 per cent plus one. That should be the voting pattern, and that is the voting pattern. That is what is provided in the legislation. As soon as the company is private, as soon as the additional directors are elected, as soon as the board can allow, these sorts of things should be the discussion of the shareholders. And the shareholders can make those decisions whether to accept a buy-out offer or whether to continue to sell down on the stockpile at whatever rate. They can make that commercial decision.
This structure is a proper commercial structure. WoolStock Australia should be able to operate in a normal commercial way. Shareholders can elect directors. Shareholders can make decisions such as when and what price they will sell part or all of the asset, the wool stockpile. The shareholders are those wonderful wool growers of Australia, including many from the Monaro district in my electorate. They should have control of their 
 destiny, and this legislation gives that to them. I commend the bill to the House.

name: Emerson, Craig, MP
text:
—(5.09 p.m.)—I want to take the opportunity to make some relatively brief remarks on the Wool International Privatisation Bill 1999 . I do so against the background of growing up in the bush in north-western New South Wales in a town called Baradine. At the age of 16 my father lost his job. The reason he lost his job was that there was a rural recession at that time. He worked in the town in the hardware store. Associated with that recession was a decision to implement wheat quotas—for government to enter into the market and to implement wheat quotas. Also at that time there was a very sharp drop in wool prices.
As a consequence of all that, the prosperity of the surrounding farm lands had plummeted and that had affected the town itself. My father lost his job and we moved to Sydney. So I have an interest in this legislation because that whole incident brought into my mind the wisdom or otherwise of government getting involved in the sale and marketing of primary products. It did not seem to be a spectacularly successful involvement back in 1970, and I am not sure that anything we have seen in the 30 years since that  time has demonstrated that governments seeking to effectively manipulate world markets for primary agricultural products has been successful.
Against that background, I think I can say that the legislation that is before us today effectively is the end point of a set of policy decisions taken by the Labor government to get this large wool stockpile disposed of in a regular, predictable and orderly fashion. That has taken some time. As I say, the legislation does constitute the end of that road, which is pretty encouraging. But along the road, unfortunately, we have seen some major hiccups in the form of the coalition government losing its nerve at a critical time and putting a freeze on the stockpile. It is a freeze that I want to talk a little bit more about.
Back in 1991 there were just under five million bales of wool in the stockpile. Now there are around one million bales. The disposal program that had been implemented 
 by the Labor government and which was proceeding in a steady and predictable fashion came under a lot of pressure in 1997-98 largely because of the Asian crisis and weaker European demand. Those two factors pushed down the wool price. In fact, the eastern market indicator fell from 738c per kilogram clean in 1997 to 554c per kilogram at the start of 1998-99 and under 500c per kilogram before climbing again to 534c per kilogram in early April 1999.
From 1994 to 1996 Wool International was required to sell wool from the stockpile according to a very clearly fixed schedule, but a new more flexible wool stockpile disposal schedule was introduced with the Wool International Amendment Act 1996. That act required Wool International to dispose of all the stockpiled wool by 31 December 2000, to impose lower and upper caps on its quarterly sales of stockpiled wool of 90,000 and 350,000 bales per quarter respectively and to retire the debt associated with the stockpile by the end of 1998.
Then the first hiccup occurred. In March 1998 the target date for repayment of the wool stockpile debt was extended for up to six months. But then just before the federal election the coalition was spooked. The person who did the spooking was Pauline Hanson and Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party. They were so worried about the impact of One Nation in the bush that a decision was taken by the coalition cabinet to place a freeze on the stockpile. That decision was quite contrary to the recommendation of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and I think it is reasonable to expect that it was also contrary to the position of the Deputy Prime Minister.
So the question must be asked: if the primary industries minister and the Deputy Prime Minister opposed a freeze on the stockpile, who supported it? The answer is that Pauline Hanson supported it; she was in effect in the cabinet room on that day. The other people who supported it would have to have been the Western Australian Liberal Party. So we had a situation where the National Party was rolled by the Liberal Party of Western Australia. Of course, the position was 
 supported by Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party, because they had announced that it was their policy to freeze the stockpile. On 21 December last year the law was enacted to officially freeze the sale of wool from the stockpile until the end of June this year when Wool International was to be replaced by a private company—WoolStock Australia. Today we are debating the enabling legislation for that.
The decision to freeze the stockpile was a folly. There are some estimates that it cost Australian wool growers up to $20 million in the form of interest charges and extra storage fees. What did it achieve? It achieved absolutely nothing. There has been no positive impact on the international price of wool from this decision to freeze the stockpile. It was an ill-conceived policy with no benefit to farmers. In fact, the effect of moving from a scheduled, predictable reduction in the stockpile to a temporary freeze was to add unnecessary uncertainty in the international wool market. So it is reasonable then for buyers to respond to that by wondering when the resumption of the disposal of the stockpile may occur.
It is quite possible—in fact I think likely—that the decision to freeze the stockpile, by creating added uncertainty, actually could have contributed to weaker prices in the international wool market. We have a situation where the coalition government almost clutched defeat out of the jaws of victory by implementing this freeze. Yet again we have an example of the National Party letting down the bush.
—Are you one of these economic rationalists?
—I hear from the member for Kennedy. The second example that we have of the National Party letting down the bush is in last night's budget where, of course, the National Party acquiesced to the full sale of Telstra by having all of the proceeds from the full sale of Telstra incorporated into the budget. It is there in the documents for all to see, including the member for Kennedy. I would be fascinated to hear what his reaction is to the fact that his National Party colleagues in the cabinet have sold out 
 the bush by agreeing to the full sale of Telstra and completely reneging on the promise that they made, that the Deputy Prime Minister made, that there would not be a full sale of Telstra unless an independent inquiry found that service provision in the bush was adequate. We know that, as a result of the decisions taken in putting that budget together, there is absolutely no point in that inquiry proceeding, because the decision has already been made. In the freeze of this wool stockpile we have a classic example of the National Party letting down the people of the bush. That same pattern was repeated in last night's budget, with the National Party yet again letting down the bush and provincial Australia.
I find it fascinating that the coalition is against a national coal authority on the basis that they do not believe that a national coal authority could effectively and positively influence the international price of coal. I happen to agree with them on that point, yet they have believed that a national wool authority can affect the world price in a positive way. I would be very interested in hearing from the National Party the explanation for their belief that a national wool authority can affect to our advantage the international price of wool but that a national coal authority cannot do the same with respect to coal. My own belief is that neither of them can in the long term produce good results for rural Australia.
We do have to recognise that synthetics and other countries offer very genuine and tough competition for Australian wool. As a result of that we are not effectively price setters in the international market for wool. So now we have the creation through this legislation of WoolStock Australia, effectively a privatised company. It is a policy that was announced by the Labor government several years ago. It has been a fair while coming. As I say, there have been a number of major hiccups along the way as the National Party and the coalition government have intervened in this process and implemented a very silly policy of a freeze in the stockpile.
Having said that, I am happy to wish WoolStock Australia very well. I note that in 
 the constitution for WoolStock Australia, to be approved by the minister, is the provision of up to $300 million—about 0.6 per cent of the estimated net value of the stockpile—be used for the purpose of investigating and sponsoring new business activities. We heard from my colleague the member for Lyons. He believes that there is capacity for a privatised corporation to come up with more innovative business activities and marketing strategies, perhaps more innovative than a more constrained operation that has been held in government ownership could come up with.
The member for Calare raised the issue of whether the government really is getting out of wool marketing. The proposal is for the appointment to the board by the government of the first three positions in this new privatised organisation on the board, with the rest of the board to be appointed by the first three directors. There is a realistic situation, which I hope does not emerge, where the government can very strongly, at least initially, influence the policies and behaviour of this privatised board. I hope that will not be the case. I accept that there is possible justification for this in the transition to a fully independent board.
I end on this note, Mr Deputy Speaker. I would be very interested to hear from the member for Kennedy who is to speak next. I would also be very interested to hear from the member for Dawson who is not here but often has opinions that she likes to express. I would be interested to know just what their attitudes are to the very disappointing and shameful decision that has been taken in the context of the budget to completely repudiate the commitment that the National Party made that there would not be a full sale of Telstra unless an independent inquiry—and I emphasise `independent'—was first convened and unless that independent inquiry found that there was adequate provision of services by Telstra.
Neither of those things is really going to happen because an official government decision, as incorporated in the budget figures, has been made to fully privatise Telstra. As a result we can certainly expect to see yet a further withdrawal of services in rural Aus 
 tralia. That has been condoned by the National Party—by the member for Kennedy, who would have been in the party room, and by the member for Dawson when both honourable members said before the election that they would go to the barricades on this issue of the privatisation of Telstra. They have rolled over and have had their tummies tickled. They are obviously quite happy now to sign up to the full privatisation of Telstra with no independent inquiry and with no safeguards on the future service provision by Telstra.

name: Katter, Bob, Jnr, MP
text:
—If only I had two hours but I will have to make do with what I have got. The spirit of Mark Latham is not dead in the Labor Party, I can see, and it worries me greatly that there are people like this in the Labor Party. I thought they had learnt their lesson after the terrible hiding they got in the last election after imposing 12 years of economic rationalism on this country. I do not cast aspersions on the Leader of the House at the present moment, because I think he got punished severely for having the temerity to question the policies of economic rationalism, and we applaud Mr Swan for his courage at the time.
One of my good friends, a journalist from Queensland and one of the people from my own homeland, the mid-west of north Queensland, wrote in an article recently that only sheep have to wear wool. That is the problem for the sheep growers. The basic point that she is making is that we have to accept the world market price. There are no great characteristics about wool which ensure that people will have to wear wool as they wear leather shoes.
The National Geographic had a cover story on wool some years ago. It was an excellent article. It said that wool has three times the absorption rate of almost all other fibres. This is a very important characteristic, as you would be well aware, particularly with respect to clothing. The Mongols of the deserts west of China use it for raincoats, blankets, tents and everything known to man, and it has been very effective in providing a range of virtually everything that they need in the way of clothing and protection from the elements.
Wool has a property of non-combustibility. One of the excellent advertising campaigns is done by the group from Toowoomba that sells wool insulation. The lady involved puts the artificial fibre on top of the wool fibre in her hand, strikes a cigarette lighter, and then burns the insulation material. She then puts it down on the desk and there is a bright flame. It graphically illustrates the enormous insulating properties that wool has, which makes it such a remarkable fibre. In an age when we have natural and renewal fibres that are all the rage, it should be a commodity coming into its own because it is a natural and renewable fibre. The trend and the fashion would indicate that wool should be flying high.
I was a very young man in the dark days of wool in the last 1960s and because my father was a member of parliament—and even before he was a member of parliament—I went to a number of the meetings. It was clear to me that wool was finished. In the 1960s many of us decided that wool was a commodity that had no place in the modern world. Labour costs in this country and throughout the world were soaring and, of course, it was a high labour input commodity. Therefore, it had no place in the modern world.
We had gone through a long period of drought at that time in Australia and it was clear that it was very difficult indeed to make a profit in wool, or in cattle for that matter, because of the dry nature of this continent. That was the second reason people like me decided that there was no future in wool.
It was the age of artificial fibres. We all thought we were very suave and up-market when we ran around in our nylon shirts. They abraded us underneath the arms but we wore them because we were a bundle of style in those nylon shirts. But after a while the style wore off and the abrasions became quite acute so we moved back to cotton and more natural fibres.
The third area was mechanisation. It was an age where if you could not mass-produce an item with machines then, clearly, that was an item that we should not have; it should not exist. For all of those reasons there was no faith in that industry whatsoever. Those 
 people who took a longer view—I did not—looked at wool and said, `It has been around for about 10,000 years. As long as man has been man it has been around, so maybe there is some value in it.' Those people who made those financial decisions made an awful lot of money.
At the time, there was a politician of some considerable force and some considerable leadership in this country, and he took a position which was not the position of the official spokesmen of the industry. The official spokesmen of the industry believed we should stay on the free market system, in spite of one of the finer intellects the country has produced in agriculture, Sir William Gunn, advocating strongly that we should involve ourselves—that is, the government or semi-government instrumentalities or the producers acting collectively—in the marketplace, but he was ignored. In fact, he had tomatoes thrown at him on three or four occasions at meetings that he had addressed where he had put up his `communistic proposal', as it was called at the time.
That very famous Australian, who deserves very, very great accolades from all of this nation, was Doug Anthony. I am very proud to say that he was the Leader of the National Party. Doug decided to do what he did in spite of the fact that the industry leadership said, `No, we want a free market system,' in spite of the fact that one of the courageous leaders, Sir William Gunn, was thrown out of his leadership position in the industry, in spite of the fact that he had tomatoes hurled at him at a number of meetings, in spite of the extreme unpopularity of that position—and in spite of the fact that he did not really have permission from the government and he did not have the clearance of cabinet. The extraordinary courage it took to do what he did was, looking back on it, quite remarkable indeed.
He started buying wool in. Any wool that came on the market—I cannot remember the exact figure; I think it was 40c cents—under 40c he brought in on a buy-in scheme. For some 18 months, in my opinion, he kept buying. The Japanese buyers stayed out of the market saying, `He will lose his nerve.' But 
 he just kept buying. Eventually, the Japanese buyers said, `Heavens, these people are serious. They really are not going to sell their wool any more under 40c.' They said, `I suppose we'll have to pay 40c.' It would have been good if the honourable member who has left the house, who was such a wonderful advocate for the policies of economic rationalism—one of Mr Latham's leadership team, obviously—had stayed here to listen, because when the minimum price scheme was introduced the price went up 300 per cent over the next two years.
For those who think that intervention in the marketplace has nothing to do with it, is it not a most remarkable coincidence that when Mr Keating removed the minimum price scheme the price went down 300 per cent in the two years afterwards? Is that not the most remarkable coincidence? The other possibility is that we are not moving in a free market system here, that we are moving in an oligopolistic market system, and maybe you need intervention in the marketplace to get a fair go. Or maybe collectively selling your product is a hell of a lot better than 50,000 of us individually selling a $6,000 million a year commodity, as it was at the time.
An argument put up is that there was a hole in the buy-in policy because there were no controls on production—and it was not possible, I would have thought, to get legislation through the House, even in those days, for controls on production, and most certainly getting agreement from the industry would have been impossible—so there was a tendency to overproduce and when the minimum price scheme was kept fairly moderate it did not stimulate overproduction. That is the argument. But on the production levels in the late 1960s, we overstimulated by one hell of a lot because we almost doubled our production of wool when the price went up 300 per cent. You can say, `Why weren't the world markets swamped, and why didn't the price collapse?' I will tell you why: because we advertised.
For those of you who like reading important books, I strongly recommend—the author was reviewed in Time magazine as being by one of the most important men of the century, 
 John Kenneth Galbraith; whilst he was not noted as one of the top 100, he most certainly got mentioned as one of the also-rans—The Affluent Society. He puts forward the proposition—and you cannot read this book without accepting the proposition—that you can affect supply by advertising. There is about a $3,000 million a year industry out there at present in Australia that says, `Yes, you can influence the demand for a product with advertising.' Of course, Doug Anthony also put in the advertising element as well.
When I buried my father I gave a speech at the funeral. One has to give a lot of thought to what are the really important things to say. At that funeral I said, `Really, the most important thing that ever happened to us west of the Great Dividing Range, in inland Australia, was the introduction of the statutory marketing arrangements in the wool industry.' For the first time in my family's lifetime, in 110 or 120 years in Australia, we saw really solid incomes, the sorts of incomes that meant we could reinvest our money with some degree of confidence in inland Australia—that was for the first time ever.
We look across the range to the sugar industry, where they enjoy an income of $89,000 per farmer per year. They have had some terrible times, believe me—they are probably going through one now—but their average income has been $89,000 for the last seven or eight years. And our average income in the wool industry is $13,000 or minus $2,300, depending on which set of figures you want to look at. I read in one recent report that in Queensland we are averaging a suicide every two months in the wool growing areas. Most certainly I know a number of people involved in the industry who have taken that terrible option.
For 18 wonderful years, we enjoyed a safe and secure income. Our little towns showed the first modicum of prosperity probably in 60 or 70 years since the Second World War. Then the terrible times occurred. A government and a Treasurer were elected in Australia that believed in this wonderful free market system. I think every intelligent person believes in the free market system. But I think also that every intelligent person realises that 
 certain markets are oligopolistic markets that are controlled by very few buyers and that you are not normally dealing with a free market system. Where you have, as you do have in the wool industry, a market that is dominated by five or six players, and where you have in Australia some 30,000 or 40,000 sellers, then you clearly have an oligopolistic marketplace. Evidence of that fact is that when the minimum price scheme was introduced the price went up 300 per cent over the next two years and when it was removed the price went down 300 per cent. I always enjoy getting into arguments when you produce that simple fact, which everyone is well aware of. Really, there is no argument that one can sustain against that very simple fact.
Mr Deputy Speaker Hawker, you yourself did a very wonderful job, in my opinion, of chairing the wool subcommittee of the coalition. You called the 17 members together on the issue of the price freeze which was criticised by the last speaker. I think there were 17 of us on the telephone hook-up that day. All 17 voted—some not—with enthusiasm maybe but most certainly with great aggression for the freezing of that stockpile. One of my great bitches—in fact, I made a very unrestrained attack upon the leadership of my own party at the time over this most important issue; that was the main burr under my saddle at the time—was the failure to freeze the stockpile. Itoh is the biggest buyer of wool, arguably, in the world. Their buyer in Australia said, `If you do not freeze the price, it is going to go down 20 per cent.' If your buyers are saying to you that you should freeze the stockpile, then I think you should really seriously look at freezing the stockpile. I thought that if we froze the stockpile the price would still go down significantly and people would say, `See, it is your fault because you froze the stockpile.' But I was absolutely confident that it would not go down anywhere near as badly if you took 15 per cent—arguably, maybe 20 per cent—of the world's supply of wool off the world's market.
Mr Deputy Speaker, as chairman of that committee, you would be well aware that that is what we did. We froze the stockpile and— 
 miracle of miracles as far as I was concerned—not only did the price not go down but it actually went up four or five per cent. I deeply regret that one of our ministers made remarks—which I hope he now regrets—that undermined the confidence in the marketplace. Then the head of Wool International made a second statement which said that it was not fully legal and undermined the confidence in the marketplace again. And then the spokesman for the wool industry councils throughout Australia made a third remark which pulled the price down again. So I hope each of the people making those remarks deeply regrets what they did to the confidence of the industry.
Let me come back to what actually happened with the collapse of the price. There was overproduction because the price had gone very high—it went to 1,200c at one stage there—and there was pressure upon the buying group at the time to put the minimum price up to 1,000c. In fact, the New South Wales farmers demanded, at one of their conferences, that it go to 1,000c. They fought off that temptation, but they had to yield a bit, so they went to 870c a kilo. Mr Kerin and Mr Keating had three infamous press conferences. At each of those press conferences—and I watched all three of them—they clearly indicated to the world market that the Australian government would no longer stand behind the price for wool. Mr Keating was very ideologically driven. The member for Petrie suffered his violence. So also did Senator Button, who was a very great loss to this place. But by making those statements they undermined the confidence in the marketplace. You have to understand that what happened here, Mr Deputy Speaker, was like a service station owner putting up a big sign saying that petrol was going to be 30 per cent a litre cheaper next week. So everybody stopped buying petrol, because they were going to fill the tank the next week when it would have been 30 per cent cheaper. That is exactly what the world wool buyers did. They said, `These blokes are not going to stand behind the minimum price scheme. Clearly the Australian government thinks the price is going to go down. We had better stop buying here.' So, of course, they stopped buying, and
