 the price went through the floor because the confidence in the marketplace had been broken by Mr Kerin and by Mr Keating. They were the people who were responsible.
Before those infamous press conferences, the price of wool was 890c a kilo and the minimum price was 870c a kilo. We had about a 20 per cent buy-in, if my memory serves me correctly. Whilst 20 or 30 per cent, whatever it was, was a high buy-in level, there was nothing dramatically wrong with the system. But after those infamous press conferences, of course, there was a hell of a lot wrong. The buyers just withdrew en masse from the marketplace. Then Mr Keating used his own destruction of the confidence in the marketplace as an argument—which he intended all the time of course—to dismantle the minimum pricing arrangements because of his profound, blind, ideologically driven belief that everything had to be determined by the marketplace. Someone should have explained to Mr Keating about oligopolism and the influence on the marketplace of a few buyers meeting so many sellers.
This brings me to the final point I want to make. The United Graziers Association has been a very conservative body that really always tends to favour a free trade position. John Hamilton from Nelia in North Queensland said to them, `Mr McGauchie, I am not interested in this buying group providing shares and great share value. I am not interested in share value. I am interested in the value of the price of the wool. I am not a share trader. I am a wool producer.' Almost every single one on that council backed Hamilton very strongly. I would hope that the minister and Mr McGauchie take into consideration that there is a group out there—as Mr McGauchie, strangely enough, said in his own speech that day—who prefer to sell into the spikes rather than into the troughs. If they perform in the marketplace, they most certainly can affect it and they can move back towards the sort of situation which kept us a very happy industry and in prosperity we had never dreamed of for nearly two decades in the bush. I would plead with everyone who is a decision maker involved in this to look back 
 to those golden years and to learn the lessons from the history of this industry.

name: Vaile, Mark, MP
text:
—in reply—Firstly, may I thank all members who have participated in the debate on the Wool International Privatisation Bill 1999 . It is a historic and quite significant bill in terms of the wool industry in Australia and exactly where we are as far as the wool industry in Australia is concerned at the moment.
This bill, which provides for the conversion of Wool International into a Corporations Law company—WoolStock Australia—has received the closest scrutiny through a lengthy consultation process. As the previous speaker, the member for Kennedy, indicated, the chairman of the Interim Advisory Board, Mr McGauchie, has been consulting widely across Australia with wool growers, the shareholders and the entitlement holders in the stockpile.
It has received the closest scrutiny through a lengthy consultation process at a number of different levels. I am confident it enjoys the strong support of the wool industry. Wool International unit holders will retain their rights to share in the equity from the stockpile sales and will additionally be issued shares in WoolStock Australia. The new company will operate on a commercial basis, independent of government control, and will have a fully commercial board of directors. Importantly, WoolStock Australia will be exempt from income tax on its stockpile activities.
The rights of Wool International equity holders will be protected, although there is scope for the company to take new directions if there is strong support from shareholders to do so. Up to $3 million can be used by the company to investigate and possibly support new business activities.
Over the past few months, there has been widespread debate within the wool industry on this issue. One thing is very clear: the wool industry supports the privatisation of Wool International and can see the many benefits of a fully commercial operation free from the constraints of government influence and control.
I recently announced the appointment of Mr Donald McGauchie as chairman-designate of WoolStock Australia and Mr Reg Clairs and Mr Brian van Rooyen as directors-designate. I am particularly pleased that these prominent commercial directors have agreed to participate as members of the board at the launch of this new company. The Interim Advisory Board's work so far in developing a business plan for the new entity has been invaluable. They are well placed to manage the new company to maximise the benefit to unit holders and shareholders. Stability is the key to a profitable and successful company in the future, and these appointments provide that stability. I also believe that the unit holders have the right and the obligation to make decisions on who runs their company.
Under Corporations Law, a further three directors will be appointed by the board of WoolStock following consultation with industry. Their appointments will be subject to shareholder endorsement at the inaugural general meeting of the company, which will be held soon after conversion. As is normal Corporations Law practice, the terms of one-third of the board will expire each year. I firmly believe this process strikes a balance between the interest of the shareholders in choosing a board accountable to them and the need for stability in the critical first months of the company's existence.
The role of the trustee company received considerable focus in recent weeks during that extensive consultative process that I indicated had been undertaken. I hope that the number of shares managed by TrusteeCo will fall quickly. I am aware the board-designate of WoolStock sees as a priority the need for those unit holders whose names are incorrectly registered to be encouraged to properly record their details before the first general meeting of the company. I can confirm that the role of TrusteeCo will be an independent one. The chairman or directors of WoolStock Australia will not sit on the board of TrusteeCo. The TrusteeCo board will act only in the interests of its beneficiaries. Mr McGauchie fully supports this approach, and this should dispel any concerns that may be raised. 
The government is aware of the considerable interest in increasing the depth and liquidity of the market for WoolStock shares. While WoolStock Australia will not, at least initially, be a listed company, it is the intention of the board-designate that exempt markets for the units and shares be developed. Mr McGauchie has, therefore, initiated investigations into the development of such a market for WoolStock equity with a number of potential sponsors.
Some in the industry have indicated that some shareholders may wish the company to conduct business activities beyond selling the stockpile. This is a serious matter for the shareholders to decide and is not something for the government to be involved in. It should be decided by the new board after serious consideration of the wishes and rights of all shareholders. I believe the wool industry will support the protection being written into the company's constitution.
In conclusion, I wish to acknowledge the considerable contribution made to this process by the Interim Advisory Board, headed by Mr Donald McGauchie. The Interim Advisory Board has worked very hard not only in developing a draft business plan for the new company but in liaising and consulting with the wool industry throughout the process. The appointment of Mr McGauchie to the chair of the WoolStock board-designate and of Wool International in the period until 30 June will facilitate the transition to a private sector company. I am very conscious in particular of the uncertainties that have faced the staff of Wool International about their future, and this arrangement will assist in the bedding down of the new organisation.
We have before us this evening a new era in stockpile management. I certainly consider it a privilege to have been involved in this process of taking the decision that was taken by the government prior to the last election to the point where we are now on the verge of taking this legislation through this House and through the Senate so the rightful owners—the shareholders and entitlement holders—in that stockpile will take control in the ultimate destiny of that stockpile. I look forward to the active participation of those shareholders and 
 the new board in the management of that stockpile beyond 30 June. On behalf of the government, I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

name: Thomson, Kelvin, MP
text:
—I invite the House to cast its mind back to this day exactly one year ago, 12 May 1998, to budget day of last year. In that budget the Treasurer announced a range of initiatives relating to changes in the regulations of do-it-yourself superannuation funds. These changes included the transfer of superannuation fund regulations to the Australian Taxation Office, a lowering of the regulatory charge for DIY super funds, a new definition of the DIY superannuation funds to be called self-managed funds, changes to the penalty regime and new investment rules.
Many members may recall that there was an enormous public outcry from small business owners that run a do-it-yourself superannuation fund over the issue of the investment rule changes. The government caved in before the month of May was ended and announced that the proposed changes would not be made retrospective as was proposed by requiring funds to unwind investment decisions that they had already made.
It was, I dare say, the fastest government backflip on a budget announcement in the history of the Commonwealth parliament. It was also an example of policy making on the run and by press release. But it is an indictment of the government that we are debating this bill today on the first anniversary of the 1998 budget announcement. It indicates the contempt with which the Howard-Costello government has treated superannuation fund members, the trustees and the fund administrators, beginning with the superannuation surcharge tax in the 1996 budget, the abandonment of Labor's superannuation co-contribution in the 1997 budget, and now it is the turn of the DIY superannuation funds, courtesy of the 1998 budget. Indeed, it is my intention to move a second reading amendment which indicates our concern about these things. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for the financial uncertainty and hardship it has caused Do It Yourself  superannuation fund trustees and fund members, many of which are operated by small businesses, in taking nearly 12 months since it announced its changes to introduce and debate this legislation.
On the subject of the government's superannuation initiatives, the government has pulled around $5 billion out of superannuation since it came to office. The surcharge tax alone pulled out around $1.4 billion which the government claimed would be paid by higher income earners but which is actually paid by all superannuation fund members through higher administration costs and by those fund members who are under the threshold but who have not provided their tax file number to their superannuation fund.
The Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia has estimated that surcharge tax administration has cost superannuation funds some $190 million to collect, that is, $190 million less in retirement incomes that working Australians on low and middle incomes will have to spend when they retire. That is a $190 million cost to the funds themselves. I have, in fact, asked the Treasurer a set of questions on notice about how much it is costing taxpayers to collect all this. So far he has not responded to that question. I might have to have a word to the Speaker about that in due course.
Senate estimates last week revealed that some 65,000 surcharge tax assessment notices would be sent to fund members who have not provided their tax file numbers to their fund or to the tax office. I expect that many of those members would not be high income earners at all.
Last night's budget quantified the backflip made by the government in abolishing the advance instalment of the superannuation surcharge tax. The government will lose $120 million in revenue in the year 2000-01, $10 million in 2001-02 and $5 million in 2002-03. The government's 1997 budget decision not to proceed with the superannuation co-contribution ripped a further $4 billion from the 
 superannuation accounts of low and middle income earners. So that is over $5 billion taken from superannuation accounts of Australian workers in just two measures. Throw in the damage caused by a flawed choice of funds policy, an announcement—but as yet no legislation—about allowing opting out, and the inclusion of superannuation assets in the means test for over 55s, effectively forcing older Australians to fund their own unemployment benefits, and you get a picture of the disdain with which this government has treated superannuation and collective savings vehicles in general.
You also get a picture of a government which has no retirement incomes policy of its own and one which is trying to tear down the world-leading, best-practice policy established by successive Labor governments. Having done that damage, ringbarking Labor's superannuation tree, this government then turned its beady little eye to the excluded superannuation funds.
This bill gives effect to the government's 1998 budget changes to the regulation of small superannuation funds and to a recommendation of the financial system inquiry known as the Wallis inquiry. It amends the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act of 1993, or SI(S) Act, and a range of other related financial services, taxation and superannuation acts, firstly, to establish a new category of small superannuation fund with fewer than five members, to be called a self-managed fund, where all the members of the fund must have a business or family relationship, that is, a non-arms-length relationship, and all of them must become trustees of the fund.
Secondly, it transfers the regulation of self-managed funds from the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, or APRA, to the Australian Taxation Office, with effect from 1 July this year—so it is coming up very soon. Thirdly, it provides for a reduced supervisory levy, from $200 to a maximum of $50, to be payable by self-managed superannuation funds.
I have already said that this government ought to be condemned for the delay in introducing this measure which was first 
 announced on 12 May last year—so its anniversary this year—but was not introduced to the parliament until 31 March. The generous Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp—and more on him later—released an exposure draft but provided only two weeks for interested parties to comment: a measly two weeks, when the government took almost a year to produce and release an exposure draft. That is nothing short of contemptuous. This delay has caused unnecessary uncertainty especially amongst small business owners.
Let me turn firstly to the new definition of self-managed superannuation funds and fund membership changes. The DIY superannuation funds are currently subject to less onerous prudential regulation than larger funds, which come under control of the SI(S) Act and its regulations. This is based on the presumption that most DIY fund members are closely associated with the fund and its trustees and are likely to be able to represent their own interests as non-arms-length members. Some 16 per cent, or approximately 30,000 of the 180,000 DIY funds, contain arms-length members—that is, members who are not closely related to the fund sponsors—who might not be able to protect their interests in the superannuation fund and who do not have the prudential protection of the regulator, APRA.
To overcome this potential problem the bill requires all members of a self-managed fund to be family members or business relations, on the assumption that family members or business partners will be able to look after their own interests. In addition, all fund members will be required to become trustees. A member who does not into one of those categories will be transferred out of the fund. Alternatively, the fund may not wish to be a self-managed fund, in which case it either has to appoint an independent trustee and be regulated by APRA or has the option of winding up.
The government has not provided any evidence in support of this change which will inconvenience many small superannuation funds, many of which are run by small businesses. While anecdotal evidence exists that some arms-length fund members may not 
 have adequate protection of their interests, the government has not provided evidence of this. In addition, the bill will also force fund trustees to expel some arms-length fund members, potentially incurring substantial costs to the funds, its members and the transferring member. This has caused considerable consternation amongst those small businesses which operate a DIY fund.
However, there is also anecdotal evidence which suggests that some DIY funds may be using their fund assets for investments which are not in the long-term interest of arms-length members. So, in that instance, you have arms-length fund members having little protection, and they may benefit from these changes. We think that the government needs to justify its decision to change the status of self-managed superannuation fund members.
Secondly, I want to address the regulation transfer from APRA to the ATO. This has been described, let me say, by one highly regarded superannuation commentator as `like putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank'. I have to say that the Taxation Office, for its part, has been at some pains to assure us that this is not the case. Small superannuation fund operators and their accountants or administrators are worried that the ATO not only will crack down on people allegedly rorting the system but also may take a stricter line with funds which appear to be operating within the law.
While this measure is in line with a Wallis inquiry recommendation, it appears to be based on the fact that it is impractical for APRA to do anything but superficially regulate these funds. APRA generally conducts field audits and would require large additional resources to have any hope of auditing the 180,000 DIY funds it currently regulates. By way of comparison and contrast, there are only 5,000 industry, retail, corporate and public sector funds.
The fact is that APRA, and the ISC before it, could not effectively regulate DIY funds which did lead to anecdotal evidence of abuse of investment rules and possible taxation rorts. Transfer of the regulation power to the ATO may curtail this if it is occurring. How 
 ever, it is up to the government to provide evidence that it is in fact occurring.
Before the Wallis inquiry, superannuation funds were only regulated by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, or ISC. The transfer of prudential regulation for self-managed super funds to the tax office will result in superannuation being regulated by three different entities—APRA, ATO and the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, or ASIC. This, in my view, is in direct contrast with the main Wallis recommendation that essentially only two bodies—APRA and ASIC—should be responsible for the regulation of the financial services sector.
The third issue is that of a reduced supervising levy to be payable by self-managed super funds. Until the formation of APRA last year on 1 July, all superannuation funds paid $200 and larger funds paid a percentage of their assets to cover the costs of their regulation. APRA claims that the $200 paid by DIY funds cross-subsidised the prudential regulation of larger funds. Changes to the levy structure within APRA and the removal of the supposed cross-subsidy by capping the amount payable by the DIY funds to $50 have led to larger superannuation funds now paying substantially more in their prudential regulation levies. That means lower retirement incomes on the part of members of larger superannuation funds, who are more likely to be low and middle income earners. Very few low and middle income earners are in DIY funds, which are predominantly recommended to persons with more than $100,000 to invest, although some may be arms-length members.
There has been little evidence produced to date to support the argument that DIY fund levies were subsidising larger superannuation funds. The government is using the lowering of levies for self-managed funds as an offset to other changes, including changes to investment rules which are the subject of a draft Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1999, the one which deals with the investment rules. This bill raises more questions than answers. It should be subject to a thorough investigation by a Senate committee. The principal aims of the bill are to protect arms-length members, essentially by eliminat 
 ing them, and to bring self-managed funds into closer tax scrutiny. However, it is still not clear whether this change is necessary.
I have received correspondence from a range of industry practitioners, who have raised some technical deficiencies, which I will touch on here but which may best be raised and considered by a Senate committee inquiring into and conducting hearings concerning the bill. One of the key issues appears to be that if a fund is forced to transfer an arms-length member out of the fund because that person is not a trustee it could trigger a capital gains tax liability for the fund, the member or both. The question arises as to whether the government should provide rollover relief if a capital gains tax liability is triggered.
In addition, the Australian Taxpayers Association has raised the issue of the size of the self-managed funds being less than five members. What if a family has three members who are members of the fund? This could present problems in certain situations. The issue has also arisen as to whether there could be a clash with another piece of legislation, the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 , which provides provisions for fund trustees to accept binding death benefit nominations. Under the current law governing excluded funds, a same sex partner may be able to be nominated as a dependant for the purposes of receiving death benefits. However, under the new rules the same sex partner may not be able to be nominated in the same manner. This issue has been raised by the private member's bill of the member for Grayndler and is one which perhaps should be examined further in the context of this bill.
The issue of single trustee funds has also been raised as an issue which is worthy of further examination. The explanatory memorandum states that changes to the superannuation supervisory levy are expected to have a budget revenue cost of around $19 million on each of the financial years 1999-2000 to 2001-02. However, the Treasury stated in a briefing on this bill that they expect this revenue to be recouped through user charging principles applied by the tax office and by APRA. So the opposition will not be oppos 
 ing the government's bill. Instead we will refer it to a Senate committee for examination. Whatever the merits of this bill, it is disappointing that the government has kept the DIY funds waiting for so long on an uncertain footing. The government ought to be condemned by this House for doing so.
In the period since the government made its announcement—back in the budget of last year, in fact—there was evidence that the rate of increase in the establishment of do-it-yourself superannuation funds had declined by half, from 1,000 to 500 each week. This was reported in the 1999 edition of Superfunds in an article by Susan Hely which went on to say:
The main reason behind the decline is the new investment rules announced in May 1998, according to Daniel Butler of Daniel Butler and Associates, who . . . said that the superannuation surcharge had also been a significant factor.
So it is significant to note that there has been that dip in the growth of DIY funds since the government made this announcement. I also draw the attention of the House to a report by Michael Laurence concerning the issue of changes in the superannuation rules. This article was entitled, Super rules, super anger . He stated:
North Queensland financial planner Kevin Hardwick is deeply disturbed by successive federal coalition proposals that are eroding the tax advantages of all super, particularly DIY schemes. "What is happening is a tragedy for country towns," says Hardwick . . .
"In rural Queensland, self-managed funds invest in the local economies," Hardwick says. "They buy the premises of the local panel-beating shops and banks to act as landlords. The funds buy blocks of land to develop and to generate eventual retirement income. Local builders and other businesses get all of the associated work."
They were very concerned about the impact of government changes. I will quote once more from Michael Forsdick who said:
The tax breaks of super are simply disappearing. The tax package all but removes the tax benefits of super for those earning less than $75,000; those earning above $75,000 already get precious few tax breaks from super anyway. Superannuation is being hammered.
The article continues:
In interviews with eight super specialists, highly emotive words were used to describe the coalition's super measures since coming to office; for example, `attack by stealth', `doesn't realise the implications of what it is doing', `another nail in super's coffin'.
This is the very strong language used by those who are familiar with the changes made by this government to superannuation. In addition, in this area, I received—and no doubt other members received—correspondence from a number of bodies which are familiar with and concerned by these changes. For example, in March of this year I received correspondence from Managed Superannuation Services with the heading `Proposed changes to superannuation fund investment rules creating confusion and eroding confidence'. They said:
We are writing to you because we are concerned about and committed to encouraging growth, competition and confidence in our superannuation system—concern and commitment that we fear are not shared by the Federal Government.
They then talked about their own company, and said:
By way of background, we are a superannuation administration and advisory company providing services to and representing the trustees of more than 2,000 superannuation funds, which in turn comprise in excess of 10,000 members. The majority of those funds are representative of the small business community, with a substantial exposure to the regional and rural sector.
. . .              . . .             . . .
We are disheartened and frustrated by the Government's apparent lack of regard for such an important issue as superannuation. This was exemplified last May when the Government announced in its Budget that new investment rules would apply to superannuation funds.
That is an example of the concern which they were expressing. They pointed out that, in the 10 months since those measures were announced, there had been no supporting legislation and it had put fund trustees in a most invidious position. They said:
. . . it is unclear exactly how the measures are intended to apply and superannuation fund trustees have been left with the following options:
.	 to defer any investment decisions until the relevant legislation is introduced;
.	 to only invest in areas that are potentially beyond the scope of the new restrictions; or 

.	 to continue to make investments in line with an existing strategy but in an environment of total uncertainty.
None of those options is desirable.
It was really unfair to trustees that the government was putting them in that position for a period in excess of 10 months. It was quite unconscionable putting fund trustees in an impossible position, not knowing whether to continue their investment strategy or change it. This problem was also described by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants as requiring the small funds to drive blindfolded:
Businesses and families have been unable to make sound decisions about their savings because they haven't been able to see everything that the Government is planning to do to their super funds.
Eventually, what we got was a backflip on those aspects of the budget announcement. It was quite clear to those of us who had been following this debate that Treasurer Costello had been rolled by small business minister Peter Reith. Frankly, the Treasurer had only himself to blame, given that the delay in acting on the budget announcement was quite unconscionable and trustees had been put in that situation. The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business could not resist visiting the scene of the crime. One day after the Assistant Treasurer put out the press release indicating the backflip, the minister for small business put out his own press release regarding the small business superannuation backflip.
I think one of the difficult things about superannuation that we are experiencing in Australia at the moment is that the minister responsible for superannuation, the Assistant Treasurer, simply does not have the credibility in the superannuation community or the standing within the government to ensure that superannuation is treated with proper respect and proper accord.
I note, for example, that recently in the Financial Review, concerning the disastrous handling by the government of the high rollers amendment for casinos in relation to the GST, the Assistant Treasurer was described as `pleasant but lightweight'. I think that a lot of people in the superannuation 
 industry would prefer to have a minister who was unpleasant but heavyweight—and there are a few around the parliament on both sides, I have to say!
One of the problems for superannuation in Australia in the last couple of years has simply been that the minister has been incapable of having superannuation treated appropriately seriously by this government. Indeed, in recent times the Assistant Treasurer has become something of a laughing stock as a result of his defence on the 7.30 Report and in other places of the government's GST legislation in relation to casinos. People like John Laws made him an object of contempt and ridicule, frankly, for his weak defence of what the government was doing in relation to the GST.
To conclude, we will not be opposing this legislation in the House. We will be supporting its referral to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, with a view to considering the technical issues which are raised by it and giving anyone who is concerned by any of its provisions the opportunity to appear before the Senate committee and raise those issues so they can be properly considered before the legislation is finally passed.
—Order! Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

name: Bishop, Julie, MP
text:
—In opposing the opposition's amendment and in speaking to the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1999 , I start by referring to last evening's budget. It was amply demonstrated last evening when the Treasurer delivered his fourth budget that this government is committed to ensuring that Australia provides a financially secure environment that will prosper, grow and provide greater opportunities for all Australians both now and in the future.
The Costello budget also demonstrated this government's commitment to reform—reforms in the tax system, in health, in education, in the workplace and in the financial system. Our commitment to regulatory reforms in the corporate and financial sector has already paid 
 dividends in the ability of our financial institutions, including our banks, to withstand the Asian downturn. Our emphasis on the financial services industry, with a budget commitment of $7 million of funding for initiatives to promote Australia as a centre for global financial services, is a testament to the reform agenda that was undertaken as soon as the coalition came into government.
It was back in June 1996 that the Treasurer established the financial systems inquiry with a mission to provide a stocktake of the results arising from the financial deregulation of the Australian financial system since the early 1980s. The forces driving further change were to be analysed and recommendations were to be made on the nature of the regulatory arrangements that would best ensure an efficient, responsive and competitive financial system to underpin strong economic performance consistent with financial stability, prudence, integrity and fairness.
The report that resulted from this inquiry into the finance industry made a series of recommendations in the area of financial regulation designed to improve market conduct, disclosure, safety, stability, competition and competitiveness. Pertinent to this bill before the House, the inquiry made a number of recommendations concerning the regulation of superannuation funds. Not surprisingly, the administrative complexity of superannuation arrangements and compliance costs had been a matter of serious concern to both the industry and the consumers.
Given the expected growth in superannuation as a proportion of household and financial system assets and given the fact that superannuation is the largest component of the funds management industry in this country, reforms leading to improvements in the regulatory framework for superannuation funds have been a priority of this government. Australia finds itself in company with all other industrialised nations where ageing populations are placing increasing pressure on government funded pensions and programs. We are about to experience a huge demographic shock as the population over the age of 65 increases and the population paying tax decreases, and the consequential number of 
 retirees in our society will have profound implications on the economic and fiscal wellbeing of our ageing population.
The government's commitment to superannuation reform is a response to this situation and is designed to encourage individuals to take greater responsibility for their retirement funding and to ensure that their retirement security is adequate to meet increases in life expectancy and to meet the saving challenges on those who retire early. We have the opportunity now to make changes to our superannuation legislation in order that individuals can take this greater responsibility for the management of their funds and can protect their particular interests. The timing is opportune as the baby boomer generation swirls the ranks of the aged and the retirees simultaneously deplete the ranks of the working population as they resort to their retirement funding.
The government has acted on the recommendations of the inquiry and, in the 1998-99 budget, announced changes to the regulation of self-managed superannuation funds known as excluded superannuation funds. An exposure draft was released for public comment and industry consultation and numerous responses were received. This bill—No. 3—to amend the superannuation legislation gives effect to the 1998-99 budget announcements. It reflects the government's response to the financial systems inquiry as it pertained to small superannuation funds and the regulation of those funds. It takes account of the views of the large number of industry bodies who made submissions to the draft bill.
The issue addressed by this bill relates to excluded superannuation funds. The government's aim is to ensure that all members of excluded superannuation funds are able to better protect their interests. The objective is to amend the definition of an excluded superannuation fund. Put simply, it is a fund with fewer than five members. Excluded superannuation funds are subject to less onerous prudential requirements under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, the SI(S) Act. This act regulates all superannuation entities, including industry funds, public offer 
 funds, employer related funds as well as excluded superannuation funds.
Excluded funds are exempted from onerous requirements, such as the requirement to establish internal complaints resolution systems, the requirement to have a registered company auditor and many other detailed requirements for the reporting to members. Excluded funds are exempted from these requirements on the basis that members of the fund are capable of looking after their own interests. This is on the assumption that they are related—husband and wife or business partner arrangements and the like—and this is normally the case. In these situations, the members usually act as trustees and therefore have control or can manage the  administration of the fund.
This is all well and good, but a situation has arisen over time where excluded superannuation funds have included members who are not in any position to protect their own interests, in that they have no control. This is because the definition of excluded funds does not currently require a relationship or a particular common interest between members, and it does not have any requirement or does not ensure that all fund members have equal power or influence within the fund.
The obvious examples where an excluded fund can include members who are not in a position to protect their own interests are where a family fund has been extended to include a non-related employee of the fund's employer/sponsor. The employee becomes an arms-length member. This person generally has no relationship with the other members and thereby lacks a commonality of interest with the other members. The situation also arises that, as the employee is not normally a trustee or related to a trustee, that person lacks the equality of influence or power within the fund and therefore is not able to be involved in trustee decision making and, consequently, is not able to adequately protect their interest, or is at least exposed to that very real possibility.
This bill amends the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act to establish this new category of small superannuation fund with fewer than five members, to be called a self- 
 managed superannuation fund. The new definition of a self-managed superannuation fund will require that, in addition to the fund having fewer than five members, all members of the fund have a business or family relationship and be trustees of the fund.
According to the bill's explanatory memorandum, at present the number of excluded superannuation funds has grown rapidly from around 60,000 in 1991 to a current estimate of 180,000, representing some $42 billion in assets under management. Excluded superannuation funds comprise 97 per cent of the total number of funds but account for only 12 per cent of total industry assets and 1.8 per cent of fund members.
The annual return data from the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority indicates that approximately 16 per cent of excluded superannuation funds contain arms-length members, that is, members who are not relatives or associates of trustees of the fund—so people who are not in a position, as we put it, to look after their own interests. Being excluded superannuation funds, they are exempted from the prudential requirements which in other circumstances would give the protection of additional prudential requirements which are otherwise available to protect members in such a situation.
Therefore, the amendments will ensure that an excluded superannuation fund—to be renamed a self-managed superannuation fund—will contain only members who have a commonality of interest, either related or business partners, and that all members be trustees, and it provides the mechanism for all members of such a fund to be involved in trustee decision making. The amendments also ensure that any current excluded fund containing arms-length members who would be in need of prudential protection and do not choose to transfer those members out of the fund will not be classified as self-managed superannuation funds. They will remain regulated by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority and, therefore, the prudential requirements from which small funds are usually exempt will apply to protect the interests of arms-length members in such funds.
The amendments provide an alternative, whereby such funds can transfer an arms-length member to a prudentially regulated fund in order to satisfy the definition of a self-managed superannuation fund with all members having commonality of interest. In essence, what this will mean is that members in excluded funds who are not trustees will be required to either transfer the arms-length members to another fund or have these members become trustees where it is possible in accordance with the act, or the excluded fund could cease to be an excluded fund and appoint an approved trustee within the meaning of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act or have the existing trustee become an approved trustee within the meaning of that act. It may well mean that approved trustee companies will see an increase in the number of small funds under their trusteeship. Arms-length members of an excluded fund can have their benefit transferred to a prudentially regulated superannuation fund and thus receive regular detailed reports, access to complaints resolution schemes and the like.
The regulation of self-managed superannuation funds will be transferred to the Australian Taxation Office from 1 July 1999. That is very soon. The regulation of all others remains with the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority. The change in the definition will not impose a cost on all self-managed superannuation funds—rather only on the trustees of excluded superannuation funds that currently contain arms-length members. So it is confined to the 16 per cent. The extent of these costs will depend on whether the trustees decide to transfer the arms-length members to a prudentially regulated superannuation fund or whether the trustees wish to keep arms-length members in the fund and appoint an approved trustee.
As we move into the 21st century facing the great challenge of an ageing population living longer, we must focus on retirement savings and the protection and enhancement of them. This bill is another step in delivering an efficient, responsive and progressive framework for the regulation of self-managed superannuation funds with minimal prudential 
 regulation, but is designed to protect the interests of fund members, to encourage involvement in the management of funds and to encourage savings for retirement with a view to increasing the returns to retirees as the fund members take responsibility for their investments.
The proposed changes give arms-length members far greater access to information about their superannuation benefits, whichever option an excluded fund takes in order to satisfy the new definition. These members will receive regular information about the operations and investments of their superannuation fund, and this will give them a clearer picture of how their superannuation benefits are being managed to provide a retirement income. They will also have access to regular and detailed member information ensuring that the member is better informed about the growth of their benefits and returns. So the amendments confer powers and the administration of relevant parts of the SI(S) Act on the Commissioner of Taxation, provide for annual returns to be lodged with the ATO and remove the application of the culpability test.
Debate interrupted.

name: Nairn, Gary, MP
text:
—A few days ago I received a phone call from the chief executive of the Heinz cannery in Eden. During that phone call, I was informed that Heinz had decided to close its Eden operation. As from 30 June, the Heinz Greenseas Tuna cannery in Eden will no longer exist and nor will the jobs of its nearly 150 employees. This news is devastating to those soon to be redundant employees. It is devastating to the families, devastating to the town of Eden and devastating to the entire region.
In a region that is already suffering from low morale due to the untimely decline of its timber industry, the loss of this industry represents another blow to the Eden community, one that the community just cannot 
 afford. The Eden community needs help and it needs help from government. However, as the community seeks this help, it is becoming more and more obvious who is prepared to rally behind them and who is not. The coalition government is.
Over the last few days Centrelink has begun providing an extensive information and support service, which includes seminars at the Heinz cannery site as well as two customer service officers dedicated specifically to people affected by this closure. I thank Minister Truss for his assistance in this regard. In the next few days, a Job Network touch screen will be installed in Eden to provide better access for workers in Eden to the thousands of jobs available on the system. I thank Minister Abbott for implementing this so quickly.
Today, a delegation from the Bega Valley Shire Council travelled to Canberra to meet with federal government ministers to talk about the big picture, to examine possibilities for Eden within various federal government portfolios. With the recent cutbacks in the timber industry due to irresponsible New South Wales Labor government policy, it is vital that we actively pursue alternative industries and alternative employment opportunities for the survival of the Eden region. I thank Ministers Tuckey, who is in the House tonight, Minchin and Moore for meeting with the council delegation today at such short notice, for giving their time and for their total understanding of the issues at hand. The delegation received strong support from all three ministers, and we are now able to pursue opportunities within each of the departments.
The coalition is prepared to rally behind the Eden community. But what of Labor? The Eden community has been fruitless in its attempts to talk to the Carr Labor government. Neither Carr nor any of his ministers have yet agreed to even speak to the people of Eden. The Eden community is busily seeking alternatives. One alternative that has the potential to pull the region out of this slump is the proposed naval ammunitioning facility and the multipurpose wharf. This project has the potential to attract a wide array of 
 new industry to Eden and to provide the employment boost that Eden so desperately needs. In the budget brought down by the Treasurer last night, $3.58 million was committed to doing the necessary preliminary work on this project. The coalition is behind the Eden community.
I am very disappointed in Heinz. They have operated the Eden cannery for 25 years, and it was there for 25 years prior to that. I understand businesses make certain commercial decisions, but I believe they have done the wrong thing by the Eden community by giving them virtually no notice. There are various new industry ideas for Eden, but we need more time to develop them. Heinz should have given us at least six months, if not 12 months, notice of closure. We could have had a number of these things under way in that time, but less than two months I think was quite outrageous. I will be writing to them asking them to delay this closure so that we can provide some alternatives for the town.
I will be in Eden on Friday to talk with the community again, and I will have an officer from Invest Australia with me to provide the community with information on how they can assist. The community really is in shock, I think it would be best described, and I can very much understand some of the reactions from many people. I was in Eden last week and certainly people were very angry. Even young school children were putting petitions around, and I admire them for what they were doing in that respect to bring that community together. It is a very resilient community. It has suffered a lot of blows in the past, but there are so many superb natural features in the region.
I am very confident we will work this through. Certainly, with the assistance of a variety of ministers and departments at a federal level, they will make great gains there. I think Heinz have a responsibility to the community in which they have been operating for quite some time to do the right thing and help the community through this by giving us more time before they move that operation. (Time expired)

name: Mossfield, Frank, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on a publication called Airport Economics , written by Mr Leon Warren, who is a member of a Campbelltown anti-airport group. Mr Warren is one of many residents of Western Sydney who have taken a keen interest in the government's proposals to build Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek. One of the important issues addressed in Mr Warren's book is the suggestion that employment growth will result as a consequence of the second airport. On page 37, Mr Warren refers to a forecasting model used to estimate employment growth set out in the draft environmental impact statement on the Badgerys Creek airport. In this model it is suggested that the range of employment growth identified in Australia and overseas studies is between 500 and 800 passengers per job for direct employment and between 400 and 700 passengers per job for indirect employment. Mr Warren, in reference to this modelling, said:
The model in this case is subject to both airports in Sydney operating at their maximum capacity. The assumption suggests that employers increase their staffing levels automatically each time they exceed 400 or 800 parameters. It does not take into account improved productivity gains and increased workloads that would be borne by existing staff.
Take banks, for instance, even though their profits and the gross national product has been rising, banks are shedding staff and closing branches all over Australia.
Reference is made in this book to the general fall of employment in the aircraft industry. The FAC annual report shows that in 1996-97 the total work force in this industry was 1,180 compared to the 1992-93 figure of 1,366. At the same time passengers per employee rose from 34,271 in 1992-93 to 51,316 in 1996-97. As to whether Badgerys Creek airport will generate a large number of jobs, we have only to look at the promise of jobs made in the EIS into the third runway. I quote from Mr Warren's book:
The Department of Arts, Sports, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, in its environmental assessment report on the third runway, noted that an estimated 17,500 jobs could be generated in the airport subregion between 1995 and 2010 as a result of the operation of the new runway, with a further 27,000 jobs generated in the wider Sydney region.
No attempt has been made to measure the employment impact of the third runway, but productivity gains and reduced employment numbers reported by the FAC and airlines would indicate that there has been no employment gains.
I would like to congratulate Mr Warren on his important contribution to the Badgerys Creek airport debate and wish him and his organisation well in their future campaign.

name: Kerr, Duncan, MP
text:
—This debate deals with two related bills—the Customs Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999  and the Import Processing Charges Amendment Bill 1999 . The 
 first bill proposes to amend the Customs Act 1901 by introducing a new reporting and registration scheme for bulk cargo consignments of high volume, low value cargo into Australia. The second bill proposes to amend the Import Processing Charges Act 1997 to reduce the screening charges to apply to those who register as special reporters under the scheme to be established by the first bill.
The Customs Act requires pilots of aircraft and owners of ships to report to the Australian Customs Service information about cargo intended to be discharged at a port or an airport in Australia. The Australian Customs Services uses these reports to screen cargo and to carry out its responsibility to protect Australia against the importation of prohibited goods. The proposed reporting and registration scheme that these bills envisage is designed for high volume cargo such as documents and consolidated mail orders which are valued at less than $250 per consignment and transported by specialist operators. Currently, such consignments are reported at a consolidated level and the Australian Customs Service relies on physical random checks to inspect individual consignments.
The new scheme is intended to allow operators who register as `special reporters' to report cargo at a consolidated level, provided the ACS has access to their computer facilities where information relating to individual consignments is stored. Operators by registering would be aware and agree that the Australian Customs Service would have access to their relevant computer databases and would be able to make necessary privacy and security arrangements if this is a matter of concern to them.
The powers to the ACS under new subdivision D would ensure compliance by special reporters with the conditions and requirements in amendments to division 3 which establish the new registration and reporting scheme. These powers appear to be comparable to existing powers and provisions of the Customs Act which deal with search warrants in respect of things believed to be evidential material.
This scheme is intended, effectively, to enable a smoother transition of product of this nature through the border control, to enable Customs to work with those who are registered under the scheme to undertake appropriate checks through the course of their import. As the scheme will be less expensive to manage than the current arrangements, the government has made consequential proposals to reduce the charges for reporting under the new scheme. That, of course, is a consequential and, I assume, not unwelcome concession by the government in relation to the arrangements that they have proposed.
In relation to the working of Customs, this is an agency which is in considerable crisis at the moment. Customs has faced challenges which, plainly, it has failed to discharge, not the least being the two instances whereby large vessels sailed down the east coast of Australia and beached—one in Queensland and one in New South Wales—avoiding coastal surveillance. We are aware that there have been large and increasing consignments of illicit materials, particularly drugs, coming into this country at a rate which the government concedes is such that the availability and purity of those drugs is higher than ever before.
Of course, this has had consequences in Minister Vanstone's own administration of the department. Her department is operating with a crisis of morale. Within Customs, there is a real sense that the arrangements that the government has put in place necessary to provide support to them have been inadequate. There are now currently major inquiries being pursued as to the future arrangements that should apply in the area of the management of Customs 
 resources. It is widely believed that Customs Minister Amanda Vanstone has lost the fight to prevent the breaking up of the Customs Service.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. While there is a cognate debate and therefore one would expect debate to range somewhat more widely than if the debate was on one bill only, what the honourable member is now saying is well beyond the purview of either bill. I ask you to ask him to come back to the legislation before the chamber.
—I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration. In recalling the honourable member for Denison, I am sure he will stick to the contents of both bills.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, it is not within the standing orders to require, in relation to a debate on the second reading of the bill relating to Customs, that I not speak in relation to the administrative arrangement for Customs when these matters plainly flow from changes in the processing of arrangements internally in Customs.
—I will listen very careful to what the honourable member is saying. Please proceed.
—I was simply making the point that Customs is in crisis. It is widely reported that the minister has lost the fight to keep the Customs agency in the form it is now. There have been major breakdowns in the framework for the protection of Australia's border security. The arrangements in this bill are supported by the opposition; they are convenient and appropriate. But that should not prevent us, in a debate of this nature, drawing attention to the obvious fact that the agency that is the subject of this legislation is due for a major shake-up, and to ask how that shake-up is going to be effected.
Reports that have been received from a number of sources suggest that the federal government is about to strip somewhere between 1,200 and 1,400 staff from the agency. There is an intention to create a new agency, Border Australia, to be set up with an amalgamation of these staff from Customs, 500 from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and 80 from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. And Customs is set to lose its commercial functions, which, reports suggest, will be transferred to the Department of Industry, Science and Resources, which will be responsible for the commercial side of Customs, for tariffs, antidumping and collections. So the functions now in this bill which are presently in the Customs agency will in fact be stripped from Customs and transferred to the Department of Industry, Science and Resources.
Moves in this direction were first proposed in a secret report to the Minister for Finance and Administration, John Fahey, in a bid to gain efficiencies and cost savings in border control. That so-called Sturgess report, named after its author Gary Sturgess, who is a former key adviser to the Greiner government, was handed to the Howard government last September. The secret report—the opposition has sought access to that report on a number of occasions and has been refused—is understood to have recommended the setting up of a single border agency and also to have been critical of the management of Customs. The report is also understood to have suggested that the new single border agency could be established outside the Public Service Act, with a corporate structure similar to that of Employment National, which of course has raised fears within the Customs Service of future outsourcing and privatisation. At the time of that report it is understood that Minister Vanstone opposed its implementation and succeeded in retaining the present structure. But the failures of Customs over recent times have weakened the minister's position.
The current government, after the recent election, has dusted off the recommendations of the Sturgess report. It is now part of a review which is being conducted, with Max Moore-Wilton as the chair, as part of a departmental task force set up to look at coastal surveillance and associated matters. It appears from reports that the decision has already been made, although not yet announced, that Customs will be broken up into a new Border Australia agency of the kind that I have indicated, bringing in resources from AQIS and Immigration, and that Customs will lose these commercial services that are presently the subject of this legislation. In other words, the structure that is presently in place will entirely be left. I cannot imagine what present functions undertaken by the Customs Service will be left as stand-alone agency functions for Customs if these reports are correct.
The Sturgess report was commissioned to get cost savings and to set up the border control process for possible privatisation. Labor rejects any quick fix on this. The weakness in Australia's border security needs a more comprehensive solution than simply dusting off an old, presumably rejected report and re-presenting it as a solution to a major problem that it was not designed to address. We will not be satisfied with rebadging a cost saving report. Labor is extremely wary of pea and thimble tricks after the `cost savings' of the government on law enforcement during its last term.
In relation to cost savings of the government during its last term, I was interested that the Treasurer, Mr Costello, referred last night in the budget speech to initiatives on law enforcement, particularly what he called creating a safer Australia. That took me back, because I used to be justice minister. I remember a report called the Justice Statement, which I was instrumental in the carriage of during the Keating government. The Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch, the then Prime Minister, Paul Keating, and I announced that in Queensland. In the Justice Statement there were a number of initiatives. Those initiatives were cut by the incoming government. What was included in those initiatives? What a surprise: the safer Australia initiatives and all the initiatives that were highlighted by the Treasurer, Peter Costello, last night. There they were, bold as brass.
They are damn good initiatives. But what a budget backflip—programs that were cut by the Howard government during its first term, announced by me as justice minister as part of the Justice Statement and the safer Australia initiatives, being recycled as government initiatives in the budget.
What we are concerned about here, in relation to the customs area, is that we have seen cuts right across the law enforcement areas, and the consequence of those cuts—leading to a morale loss in agencies like the Australian Federal Police and Customs—has been to weaken the capacity of those agents to be the front line law enforcement agencies that this country requires. So we are now seeing catch-up responses, renewing funding initiatives which were cut during the previous term of this government, rebadging those as Liberal government initiatives and—the worst in relation to Customs, I fear—that a proposal that was designed in the context of the previous government's attempts at cost cutting and rationalisation will be re-presented to the Australian community as if it is an answer to the crisis facing the Australian Customs Service in terms of border surveillance. That is not going to be good enough.
When I indicated that the opposition had heard these reports—we had heard that the government had already made these decisions and that announcements were likely in the near future—Minister Vanstone responded by saying that I was the subject of misleading reports 
 and my information was wrong. That puzzles me. Obviously, when my colleagues who are sitting opposite were in opposition they would have had similar reports when initiatives of this nature were in contemplation. I have had a number of reports which suggest a degree of credibility and strength on those matters beyond that which is merely speculative. The timing of the announcement and when the change will occur are something of which the sources were not aware, but the fact that those decisions had been made and were certainly widely understood throughout the department and the agencies I do not believe can be gainsaid.
We put that on record as a marker of our concern about the future. We do not want to see a recycled report, a design for an entirely different purpose, being dressed up again as a comprehensive response to what Australia needs by way of an effective border surveillance mechanism. We need to look at new initiatives. Perhaps we need to look at a type of coastguard structure. We need to look at these things more thoroughly, and there should be public input. There has been no consultation whatsoever with any of the commercial users of Customs. When there have been previous changes mooted in the administration, there has always been an undertaking to consult, not just with the unions, but also with the commercial sectors that are affected—the airlines and the shippers. They have not been consulted, notwithstanding undertakings that they would be.
Secondly, the reports as to what went wrong in relation to breaches of border security have not been made public. This is a shameful thing. When Minister Vanstone was challenged after the first boat instance, she set up her own inquiry to ascertain what went wrong and who was responsible. Somebody had to take responsibility. The minister said that she would not comment on the factual basis or responsibility until she had that report. Then a second boat sailed down the coast. It got as far as northern New South Wales.
—Scotts Head.
—Of course, you would be very concerned about that.
—I was there on the morning.
—I think you made some public comment at the time. Again, the minister said that she was broadening her inquiry, that she wanted to identify what went wrong and who was responsible. She said that she would not make comment until she had that report. A deadline for that report was imposed by the Prime Minister. That was the end of last month. The government has that report. It will not release it. The minister will still not explain what went wrong and who is responsible. Even Premier Kennett said that somebody has to take responsibility for these failures. But what we have now is a response from the government that says that these reports have just gone into the Max Moore-Wilton inquiry, and when Max Moore-Wilton tells them what they are going to do with the reorganisation that they have talked about previously they might consider releasing those reports—`might consider'.
There was a clear impression left in the mind of the community by the minister and the Prime Minister that when these reports were received they would be put out before the Australian community so that the Australian community would know that somebody accepted responsibility for these mishaps and that action would be taken to address that problem and responsibility would stand where it should fall.
It is not good enough for a government still not to speak on those incidents after those inquiries have been made, after the minister has that report, and after she must be aware of where the fault lies. All I can think is that the blame must be politically embarrassing because if the blame were not politically embarrassing those reports would be out in the public domain. 
 Why should the Australian public and its parliament, having been promised that the minister could not speak in relation to what went wrong until she had the reports, tolerate the minister still not speaking about what went wrong in two of the most publicised and significant breaches of Australia's border security after she has received an official report from her investigator and after those reports are in her hands?
What possible excuse can she provide? It is a complete contempt of the public. But worse than that, it is an effective misleading of this parliament, because those assurances were given that there would be an independent inquiry, that the minister could not speak in relation to those matters until she had that report. What is the implication drawn from that by reasonable people after they heard her say that when she had that report she would be able to detail how these events could have transpired, what went wrong, who was taking responsibility, what the processes for accountability were and how this was going to be prevented in the future? We have not heard one word. There has been silence.
What we understand, however, by way of the political reality, is that the issue has been taken out of her hands entirely. She has been left as a cipher on the sidelines. When she is asked questions about the Sturgess report—the Sturgess report was the report that I mentioned before, about the possible future of Customs and its integration into other border agencies—she says, `It's not my report. It was a report commissioned by Minister Fahey. I can't answer questions about it,'—and this was in Senate estimates—`but maybe I'll be able to say something about it at the next meeting of the Senate estimates in a fortnight.' That is in a week's time.
Again, that fits in with the fact that decisions in relation to the Sturgess report have already been taken, not by the minister, but by Max Moore-Wilton and his group, who have not had any public input; who have not called for submissions; who have not consulted the commercial community; who have not had discussions with the affected employees, their professional associations or their trade unions; but who obviously have gone back to the Sturgess report as a basis of what they intend to do.
The minister is being left out of the loop. Her opposition to the implementation of the Sturgess report seems to have been overridden. She is now having an imposed solution, firstly by Minister Fahey, who set up this inquiry into her turf, which she fought off successfully in the first instance. Now it has been passed on to Max Moore-Wilton in the Prime Minister's department. She is trying to bury the reports that she commissioned herself about what went wrong with customs operations on her watch and will not answer questions about it, because she passed those reports to Max Moore-Wilton. She is being eliminated as a minister other than in name. She has not got effective control over the future and the administration of her own department.
A minister who is a minister actually administering her department would have given the Australian public what she promised them implicitly by saying, `I will commission an independent report on what went wrong'—by presenting that and saying, `I accept responsibility for these mishaps. I have identified the failures in the system. I am taking responsibility. I am addressing the question of responsibility. If there have been acts of omission or negligence, I will ensure that they are pursued. If there have been those within my employment who have failed, I will address that. If there have been physical or technical problems in equipment and surveillance, I will identify that and address it.'
If you had a minister with control over her portfolio, those would be the responses that we would be hearing now. Instead, we have a minister whose future is being decided not by her, 
 but rather by the Prime Minister's office in an inquiry process which has no input—or, I suspect, very little input indeed—from the minister herself. I suspect that these are decisions that are being taken by other than her and imposed upon her. That is why, when pressed on these issues, we continually find a refusal to table materials which in any other circumstances would be tabled.
There is no plausible reason why a report, commissioned by the minister in the aftermath of two of the most serious instances of breaches of border security, is to be withheld from the public with no undertaking now to provide that report, even after Max Moore-Wilton completes his larger inquiry into the structure of customs arrangements. No undertaking to table it has been given.
What we are to understand essentially is that no-one is going to take responsibility for what went wrong in the past. Nobody accepts political responsibility in the Howard government for mistakes. Nobody will address the failures of equipment, performance or personnel in relation to incidents that were on the front pages of newspapers causing concern—and not just to Labor members. It might be predictable that the opposition spokesperson on justice and customs would draw attention to these matters. That is part of the role of opposition, to highlight deficiencies in government administration and call ministers to account.
In this instance, the concerns that I expressed were expressed in stronger language by colleagues of the minister. Backbench members who resided in New South Wales and Queensland expressed those concerns in stronger language than I used. I was anxious to have the matter resolved so that we had systemic solutions that would prevent this occurring in the future. They were angry that this could have been allowed to occur.
I thought the most telling remark, as I mentioned before, was from Premier Kennett, who said, `Somebody must take responsibility.' But what do we have? We have the no responsibility account. We have the cover-up approach. The minister cannot talk before she has a report; she will not talk after she has a report. When does she talk? She never talks. She never speaks to us about what goes wrong. We have just had two huge amazing episodes of—
Mr Pyne interjecting—
—She might talk about all sorts of things. She might have edifying conversations on the back bench about the factional infighting of the South Australian Liberal Party. I am certain she takes a very loud and active role in that. But in these instances, she is paid by the Australian community as minister responsible—as Minister for Justice and Customs—to be the political administrative head of a department of state—sharing it with the Attorney-General, but a joint administrator of the Attorney-General's Department, specifically charged with the responsibility for the Australian Customs Service.
When a major development occurs which demonstrates a weakness in her administration—it is on the front pages of newspapers all over the country, and is the subject of criticism by her own parliamentary colleagues and by the premiers of Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria—she says, `I cannot speak on this issue until I have a report.' When she receives the report, she says, `I cannot speak on this issue now that I have a report.' What is expected? That we will forget about it and that, with the administration of a key department of state with one of the basic responsibilities that Australia has of protecting its coastal security, an incident like this can happen without any public examination put on the table for the Australian community to be reassured that somebody is acting in their interests and that faults and failures are being addressed?
This is not part of Max Moore-Wilton's brief. Max Moore-Wilton is not set up to examine what went wrong. Max Moore-Wilton has a much wider brief to look at what departmental arrangements the government will impose on a minister who has failed.
So when are we going to hear? We still have no undertaking that there will be any accountability on this issue. The fundamental tenet of political government in Australia is what is called responsible government. What does responsible government mean? It means that, when you accept the commission of the Governor-General to become a minister, you accept political responsibility for what occurs within your portfolio watch.
This government is spurning that basic convention. We want to see that report. We will not be happy with half-measures in relation to customs services. We will not be happy with half-measures in relation to accountability. We will not be happy with the recycling of the Sturgess report, as if it is a response to these serious issues which need a much more systemic response from a government to assure the Australian public that these instances will be addressed thoroughly and properly.
—Before I call the next speaker, I would just like to make a comment pursuant to the point of order raised by the honourable parliamentary secretary. The content of these bills, as with many, is very specific and quite explicit. However, the relevant factor is the long title of the bill. I will not read it in full. But both of these bills end with the words `and for related purposes'.
When the government drafts a bill with the words `related purposes', anybody can draw a very long bow indeed. So for the information of all members, I make that point that the long title of a bill is the relevant area when we are looking at relevance.

name: Baird, Bruce, MP
text:
—It is my pleasure to speak on behalf of the government on the Customs Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1999 and the Import Processing Charges Amendment Bill 1999, which basically is mechanical in its scope. It is about introducing a new registration reporting scheme. Among other matters, it permits owners of ships or aircraft who are already registered users under the air cargo automation system or the sea cargo automation system under section 67(c) of the Customs Act 1901 to register as special reporters under the scheme.
Mr Deputy Speaker, the member for Denison certainly has drawn a very long bow. What a beat-up! This is basically a mechanical bill produced by a department to speed up the efficiency of processing of high volume, low value goods coming into the country. We have had a monumental beat-up by the member for Denison on matters which ranged to illegal immigrants coming into the country, as if there were no boat people or illegal immigrants who came into the country during the 13 years the previous administration was in office. In his extraneous examples—we have not seen this or that report—he fails to commend the minister for the excellent changes and reforms that have been carried out.
Over the past few years, my previous life has been involved in tourism and there has been a remarkable turnaround in the general approach and efficiency in the way in which Customs handled people and processed documents coming through Sydney and other airports around the country. The minister and the officers of the department need to be commended for the way in which they responded to the challenge right across the board.
The Minister for Justice and Customs is one of the outstanding ministers that we have had in this area. I have racked my brains and it is very difficult to remember any leading reforms that were carried out by the previous speaker, the member for Denison, in this area. It is amazing that we have a small technical bill on which the speaker spent about two minutes flat 
 and then spent the rest of the time having this broad ranging debate on all matters nefarious. It is a small technical bill; it is about improving efficiency.
A collection of documents—letters, legal documents, small mail-order consignments—come into the country and the process at the moment makes it difficult to follow them. The Customs Act 1901 requires that everything needs to be consigned and provided to the customs officials. This bill allows for greater efficiency in this new age of technology. We could have had a word of commendation from the member for Denison to the minister and the officers of the department to say, `Well done!' because they have recognised that the world has changed. A new technology is in place. We no longer have the comprehensive program providing all the information in the world for people to go through. The information is simply put on the computer for the customs agents to look at, and this simplifies the whole process. What could be more straightforward than that?
The member for Denison could have sat down after two minutes. He could have commended the administrators who brought this forward and left it at that. But, of course, he would have had to commend the government and the minister for what they have done.
There are different arrangements for the organisations in how they handle it. This bill provides different arrangements because of the disparity that currently exists between couriers and freight forwarders.
